{"uri": "8261077362", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "04:10:57", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T04:10:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T04:04:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/harris-readies-philadelphia-rally-introduce-040158052.html", "title": "Harris readies a Philadelphia rally to introduce her running mate. But her pick is still unknown", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Vice President Kamala Harris will introduce her new running mate at a rally Tuesday evening in Philadelphia -- but with the event mere hours away, her choice remains a mystery.\n\nIn recent days, she has zeroed in on a trio of potential finalists: Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro, Arizona Sen. Mark Kelly and Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, but decisions beyond that aren't yet publicly known.\n\nHarris' campaign planned to make the announcement via video message before the rally, though the exact timing remained unclear, according to a person involved in the planning who spoke on the condition of anonymity to detail discussions occurring behind closed doors.\n\nDoing so would be similar to how then-candidate Joe Biden revealed Harris as his vice presidential choice during the pandemic-marred presidential race of 2020.\n\nIt will mark yet another major milestone in the barely two weeks since the vice president moved to take over the top of the Democratic ticket heading into November's election. She has been scrambling to build out a campaign since then, and to breathe new life into the Democratic race against Republican Donald Trump.\n\nHarris, second gentleman Doug Emhoff and her No. 2 pick are set to appear together for an evening rally in Philadelphia, recalling a joint 2020 appearance by Biden and Harris in Wilmington, Delaware. Likewise, in 2016, newly selected running mate Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia appeared with Hillary Clinton in Miami.\n\nAfter Tuesday's day trip to Pennsylvania, Harris and her running mate will spend the next five days flying thousands of miles around the country, touring critical battleground states. They'll visit Eau Claire, Wisconsin, and Detroit on Wednesday. But a planned stop in Savannah, Georgia, was postponed due to Tropical Storm Debby 's effects, and rain associated with it could also upend a scheduled stop in Durham, North Carolina.\n\nLater in the week, Harris and her No. 2 will head to Phoenix and Las Vegas.\n\nThat the schedule was set before her running mate was identified recalls a cliffhanger-like scenario that Trump created by holding off on making his choice of vice presidential hopeful, Ohio Sen. JD Vance, until last month's Republican National Convention was under way in Milwaukee.\n\nVance, meanwhile, is aiming to detract from the debut of Harris' pick on Tuesday. He planned to arrive in Philadelphia ahead of the Democratic ticket and offer his own speech at midday, as counterprogramming.\n\nThe senator then announced he'd shadow Harris and her running mate with his own events in Wisconsin, Michigan and North Carolina. It was unclear how the weather might affect his southern swing.\n\nIn announcing Vance's travels, the Trump campaign laid the blame for a litany of woes on Harris and Democratic policies, saying that \"prices are excruciatingly high, cost of living has soared, illegal immigrants are pouring into our country, and crime is running rampant. The stock market is crashing because of weak, failed, and dangerously liberal Kamala Harris' policies.\"\n\nHarris' campaign, for its part, welcomed the overlapping destinations.\n\n\"We appreciate JD Vance providing voters in battleground states exactly the split-screen that defines the choice this November,\" said Harris campaign spokesman Charles Lutvak.\n\nThe vice president's campaign says it has invited faith leaders, union members and state and local elected officials to participate in the upcoming events. Harris and her running mate plan to rally in a variety of venues, from large arenas to college campuses. The trip will also allow them to see voters in smaller settings like union halls, family owned restaurants and campaign field offices.\n\nAt a fundraiser in Minneapolis on Monday night, Walz said Trump has stolen America's joy and was limiting freedoms.\n\n\"It wasn't a slur to call these guys weird,\" Walz said of the label he has applied to the GOP ticket in recent days. \"It was an observation.\"\n\nIt's a characterization that has since taken off in Democratic circles.\n\nIf Harris opts for Shapiro, who hails from the Philadelphia suburbs, Tuesday's event with her there would be a homecoming of sorts.\n\nConsideration of Shapiro has drawn criticism from some Arab Americans and activist groups wary of his professed solidarity with Israel in its drive to eliminate Hamas during the war in Gaza. But Shapiro enjoys strong approval ratings in Pennsylvania -- one of the Democrats' crucial \"blue wall\" states along with Michigan and Wisconsin -- that Harris will be looking to cement ahead of November.\n\nOn a \"Progressives for Harris\" organizing call Monday night that organizers said drew tens of thousands of participants, speakers repeatedly derided Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as an \"authoritarian\" who was needlessly targeting and killing civilians in Gaza.\n\nSome delegates to the Democratic National Convention who supported \" uncommitted \" rather than Biden because of his administration's backing of Israel, also suggested that they weren't yet ready to support Harris until they knew more about her policies, including if she'll work more diligently toward a ceasefire in the Gaza fighting.\n\nBut those on the call refrained from criticizing Harris' potential running mates, instead focusing on Trump.\n\n\"Trump and JD Vance are promising more tax cuts for the mega-millionaires and billionaires,\" said Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren. \"This election is our chance to tax the rich and make the wealthy pay their fair share.\"\n\nAs for Kelly, some congressional Democrats have promoted the former astronaut whose state has more than 370 miles (600 kilometers) of border with Mexico. They say his selection could help defuse Trump's arguments that the Biden-Harris administration's immigration policies are too relaxed -- though some union leaders have suggested the senator isn't as friendly to organized labor as they'd like.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kamala_Harris", {"uri": "8261091999", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "04:18:48", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T04:18:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T04:17:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national_politics/harris-readies-a-philadelphia-rally-to-introduce-her-running-mate-but-her-pick-is-still/article_ca3028f9-4d77-58fd-a8f1-9614bbfbd1ba.html", "title": "Harris readies a Philadelphia rally to introduce her running mate. But her pick is still unknown", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Vice President Kamala Harris will introduce her new running mate at a rally Tuesday evening in Philadelphia -- but with the event mere hours away, her choice remains a mystery.\n\nIn recent days, she has zeroed in on a trio of potential finalists: Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro, Arizona Sen. Mark Kelly and Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, but decisions beyond that aren't yet publicly known.\n\nHarris' campaign planned to make the announcement via video message before the rally, though the exact timing remained unclear, according to a person involved in the planning who spoke on the condition of anonymity to detail discussions occurring behind closed doors.\n\nDoing so would be similar to how then-candidate Joe Biden revealed Harris as his vice presidential choice during the pandemic-marred presidential race of 2020.\n\nIt will mark yet another major milestone in the barely two weeks since the vice president moved to take over the top of the Democratic ticket heading into November's election. She has been scrambling to build out a campaign since then, and to breathe new life into the Democratic race against Republican Donald Trump.\n\nHarris, second gentleman Doug Emhoff and her No. 2 pick are set to appear together for an evening rally in Philadelphia, recalling a joint 2020 appearance by Biden and Harris in Wilmington, Delaware. Likewise, in 2016, newly selected running mate Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia appeared with Hillary Clinton in Miami.\n\nAfter Tuesday's day trip to Pennsylvania, Harris and her running mate will spend the next five days flying thousands of miles around the country, touring critical battleground states. They'll visit Eau Claire, Wisconsin, and Detroit on Wednesday. But a planned stop in Savannah, Georgia, was postponed due to Tropical Storm Debby 's effects, and rain associated with it could also upend a scheduled stop in Durham, North Carolina.\n\nLater in the week, Harris and her No. 2 will head to Phoenix and Las Vegas.\n\nThat the schedule was set before her running mate was identified recalls a cliffhanger-like scenario that Trump created by holding off on making his choice of vice presidential hopeful, Ohio Sen. JD Vance, until last month's Republican National Convention was under way in Milwaukee.\n\nVance, meanwhile, is aiming to detract from the debut of Harris' pick on Tuesday. He planned to arrive in Philadelphia ahead of the Democratic ticket and offer his own speech at midday, as counterprogramming.\n\nThe senator then announced he'd shadow Harris and her running mate with his own events in Wisconsin, Michigan and North Carolina. It was unclear how the weather might affect his southern swing.\n\nIn announcing Vance's travels, the Trump campaign laid the blame for a litany of woes on Harris and Democratic policies, saying that \"prices are excruciatingly high, cost of living has soared, illegal immigrants are pouring into our country, and crime is running rampant. The stock market is crashing because of weak, failed, and dangerously liberal Kamala Harris' policies.\"\n\nHarris' campaign, for its part, welcomed the overlapping destinations.\n\n\"We appreciate JD Vance providing voters in battleground states exactly the split-screen that defines the choice this November,\" said Harris campaign spokesman Charles Lutvak.\n\nThe vice president's campaign says it has invited faith leaders, union members and state and local elected officials to participate in the upcoming events. Harris and her running mate plan to rally in a variety of venues, from large arenas to college campuses. The trip will also allow them to see voters in smaller settings like union halls, family owned restaurants and campaign field offices.\n\nAt a fundraiser in Minneapolis on Monday night, Walz said Trump has stolen America's joy and was limiting freedoms.\n\n\"It wasn't a slur to call these guys weird,\" Walz said of the label he has applied to the GOP ticket in recent days. \"It was an observation.\"\n\nIt's a characterization that has since taken off in Democratic circles.\n\nIf Harris opts for Shapiro, who hails from the Philadelphia suburbs, Tuesday's event with her there would be a homecoming of sorts.\n\nConsideration of Shapiro has drawn criticism from some Arab Americans and activist groups wary of his professed solidarity with Israel in its drive to eliminate Hamas during the war in Gaza. But Shapiro enjoys strong approval ratings in Pennsylvania -- one of the Democrats' crucial \"blue wall\" states along with Michigan and Wisconsin -- that Harris will be looking to cement ahead of November.\n\nOn a \"Progressives for Harris\" organizing call Monday night that organizers said drew tens of thousands of participants, speakers repeatedly derided Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as an \"authoritarian\" who was needlessly targeting and killing civilians in Gaza.\n\nSome delegates to the Democratic National Convention who supported \" uncommitted \" rather than Biden because of his administration's backing of Israel, also suggested that they weren't yet ready to support Harris until they knew more about her policies, including if she'll work more diligently toward a ceasefire in the Gaza fighting.\n\nBut those on the call refrained from criticizing Harris' potential running mates, instead focusing on Trump.\n\n\"Trump and JD Vance are promising more tax cuts for the mega-millionaires and billionaires,\" said Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren. \"This election is our chance to tax the rich and make the wealthy pay their fair share.\"\n\nAs for Kelly, some congressional Democrats have promoted the former astronaut whose state has more than 370 miles (600 kilometers) of border with Mexico. They say his selection could help defuse Trump's arguments that the Biden-Harris administration's immigration policies are too relaxed -- though some union leaders have suggested the senator isn't as friendly to organized labor as they'd like.", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@ktbs.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": {"uri": "2024-08-445209710", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "04:25:57", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T04:25:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T00:01:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2024-08-06/harris-readies-a-philadelphia-rally-to-introduce-her-running-mate-but-her-pick-is-still-unknown", "title": "Harris Readies a Philadelphia Rally to Introduce Her Running Mate. but Her Pick Is Still Unknown", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Vice President Kamala Harris will introduce her new running mate at a rally Tuesday evening in Philadelphia -- but with the event mere hours away, her choice remains a mystery.\n\nIn recent days, she has zeroed in on a trio of potential finalists: Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro, Arizona Sen. Mark Kelly and Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, but decisions beyond that aren't yet publicly known.\n\nHarris' campaign planned to make the announcement via video message before the rally, though the exact timing remained unclear, according to a person involved in the planning who spoke on the condition of anonymity to detail discussions occurring behind closed doors.\n\nDoing so would be similar to how then-candidate Joe Biden revealed Harris as his vice presidential choice during the pandemic-marred presidential race of 2020.\n\nIt will mark yet another major milestone in the barely two weeks since the vice president moved to take over the top of the Democratic ticket heading into November's election. She has been scrambling to build out a campaign since then, and to breathe new life into the Democratic race against Republican Donald Trump.\n\nHarris, second gentleman Doug Emhoff and her No. 2 pick are set to appear together for an evening rally in Philadelphia, recalling a joint 2020 appearance by Biden and Harris in Wilmington, Delaware. Likewise, in 2016, newly selected running mate Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia appeared with Hillary Clinton in Miami.\n\nAfter Tuesday's day trip to Pennsylvania, Harris and her running mate will spend the next five days flying thousands of miles around the country, touring critical battleground states. They'll visit Eau Claire, Wisconsin, and Detroit on Wednesday. But a planned stop in Savannah, Georgia, was postponed due to Tropical Storm Debby 's effects, and rain associated with it could also upend a scheduled stop in Durham, North Carolina.\n\nLater in the week, Harris and her No. 2 will head to Phoenix and Las Vegas.\n\nThat the schedule was set before her running mate was identified recalls a cliffhanger-like scenario that Trump created by holding off on making his choice of vice presidential hopeful, Ohio Sen. JD Vance, until last month's Republican National Convention was under way in Milwaukee.\n\nVance, meanwhile, is aiming to detract from the debut of Harris' pick on Tuesday. He planned to arrive in Philadelphia ahead of the Democratic ticket and offer his own speech at midday, as counterprogramming.\n\nThe senator then announced he'd shadow Harris and her running mate with his own events in Wisconsin, Michigan and North Carolina. It was unclear how the weather might affect his southern swing.\n\nIn announcing Vance's travels, the Trump campaign laid the blame for a litany of woes on Harris and Democratic policies, saying that \"prices are excruciatingly high, cost of living has soared, illegal immigrants are pouring into our country, and crime is running rampant. The stock market is crashing because of weak, failed, and dangerously liberal Kamala Harris' policies.\"\n\nHarris' campaign, for its part, welcomed the overlapping destinations.\n\n\"We appreciate JD Vance providing voters in battleground states exactly the split-screen that defines the choice this November,\" said Harris campaign spokesman Charles Lutvak.\n\nThe vice president's campaign says it has invited faith leaders, union members and state and local elected officials to participate in the upcoming events. Harris and her running mate plan to rally in a variety of venues, from large arenas to college campuses. The trip will also allow them to see voters in smaller settings like union halls, family owned restaurants and campaign field offices.\n\nAt a fundraiser in Minneapolis on Monday night, Walz said Trump has stolen America's joy and was limiting freedoms.\n\n\"It wasn't a slur to call these guys weird,\" Walz said of the label he has applied to the GOP ticket in recent days. \"It was an observation.\"\n\nIt's a characterization that has since taken off in Democratic circles.\n\nIf Harris opts for Shapiro, who hails from the Philadelphia suburbs, Tuesday's event with her there would be a homecoming of sorts.\n\nConsideration of Shapiro has drawn criticism from some Arab Americans and activist groups wary of his professed solidarity with Israel in its drive to eliminate Hamas during the war in Gaza. But Shapiro enjoys strong approval ratings in Pennsylvania -- one of the Democrats' crucial \"blue wall\" states along with Michigan and Wisconsin -- that Harris will be looking to cement ahead of November.\n\nOn a \"Progressives for Harris\" organizing call Monday night that organizers said drew tens of thousands of participants, speakers repeatedly derided Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as an \"authoritarian\" who was needlessly targeting and killing civilians in Gaza.\n\nSome delegates to the Democratic National Convention who supported \" uncommitted \" rather than Biden because of his administration's backing of Israel, also suggested that they weren't yet ready to support Harris until they knew more about her policies, including if she'll work more diligently toward a ceasefire in the Gaza fighting.\n\nBut those on the call refrained from criticizing Harris' potential running mates, instead focusing on Trump.\n\n\"Trump and JD Vance are promising more tax cuts for the mega-millionaires and billionaires,\" said Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren. \"This election is our chance to tax the rich and make the wealthy pay their fair share.\"\n\nAs for Kelly, some congressional Democrats have promoted the former astronaut whose state has more than 370 miles (600 kilometers) of border with Mexico. They say his selection could help defuse Trump's arguments that the Biden-Harris administration's immigration policies are too relaxed -- though some union leaders have suggested the senator isn't as friendly to organized labor as they'd like.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8261699027", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "11:32:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T11:32:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T11:31:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/dnc-chicago-2024/who-is-kamala-harris-running-mate-vice-president-pick/3513742/", "title": "Who is Kamala Harris' running mate? Here's who's in the running ahead of announcement", "body": "Vice President Kamala Harris officially claimed the Democratic Presidential nomination Monday night, when the Democratic National Committee released final results of its virtual roll call. Next up: Choosing a running mate.\n\nHarris is expected to announce her pick for Vice President at some point Tuesday, ahead of a campaign rally event in Philadelphia Tuesday evening. From there, the vice president and her running mate will travel to Wisconsin, Michigan, North Carolina, Georgia, Arizona and Nevada for a series of rallies to drum up support ahead of the Democratic National Convention later this month in Chicago.\n\nMinnesota Gov. Tim Walz and Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro both met with Harris for one-on-one interviews Sunday according to NBC News, and are expected to be among the finalists to be on the presidential ticket this November, according to Reuters.\n\nArizona Sen. Mark Kelly also met with Harris on Sunday according to NBC News, and Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg met with her on Friday.\n\nIllinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker and Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear have also been involved in the vetting process.\n\nSome congressional Democrats have promoted Kelly, a former Navy pilot and astronaut whose state has more than 370 miles or 600 kilometers of border with Mexico. They say his selection could help defuse Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's arguments that the Biden-Harris administration's immigration policies are too relaxed.\n\nShapiro has prominent supporters, too, like Philadelphia Mayor Cherelle Parker. She caused a stir by posting a video Friday depicting several Philadelphia-area officials and Democrats promoting Harris, but also playing up Shapiro as her running mate. A person familiar with the mayor's thinking said she had no insider knowledge about Harris' intentions.\n\nWhen asked about the veepstakes Monday, Shapiro said he had no information.\n\n\"I got nothing for you, man,\" he told an Associated Press reporter as he arrived at the Pennsylvania state capitol in Harrisburg. \"Have a great day.\"\n\nBoth Kelly and Shapiro have seen their detractors become more vocal as Harris closes in on a decision.\n\nWalz is in his second term as governor of Minnesota. He has made his state a bastion of liberal policy and, this year, one of the few states to protect fans buying tickets online for Taylor Swift concerts and other live events. He comes from rural America and in his first race for Congress, Walz upset a Republican incumbent.\n\nTrump's running mate, JD Vance, told Fox News on Sunday that Harris' pick doesn't matter to him. \"Whoever she chooses, the problem is going to be Kamala Harris' record and Kamala Harris' policies,\" he said, adding \"it's not going to be good for the country.\"\n\nThe Democratic National Convention kicks off in Chicago on Aug. 19. Harris' running mate is expected to address the convention on Aug. 21, with the vice president taking the stage on Aug. 22. {"uri": "2024-08-445232553", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "04:57:44", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T04:57:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T04:30:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.telegraphindia.com/world/kamala-harris-readies-a-philadelphia-rally-to-introduce-her-running-mate-pick-still-unknown/cid/2038937", "title": "Kamala Harris readies Philadelphia rally to introduce her running mate; pick still unknown", "body": "The US Vice President's campaign planned to make the announcement via video message before the rally, though the exact timing remained unclear\n\nVice President Kamala Harris will introduce her new running mate at a rally Tuesday evening in Philadelphia -- but with the event mere hours away, her choice remains a mystery.\n\nIn recent days, she has zeroed in on a trio of potential finalists: Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro, Arizona Sen. Mark Kelly and Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, but decisions beyond that aren't yet publicly known.\n\nHarris' campaign planned to make the announcement via video message before the rally, though the exact timing remained unclear, according to a person involved in the planning who spoke on the condition of anonymity to detail discussions occurring behind closed doors.\n\nDoing so would be similar to how then-candidate Joe Biden revealed Harris as his vice presidential choice during the pandemic-marred presidential race of 2020.\n\nIt will mark yet another major milestone in the barely two weeks since the vice president moved to take over the top of the Democratic ticket heading into November's election. She has been scrambling to build out a campaign since then, and to breathe new life into the Democratic race against Republican Donald Trump.\n\nHarris, second gentleman Doug Emhoff and her No. 2 pick are set to appear together for an evening rally in Philadelphia, recalling a joint 2020 appearance by Biden and Harris in Wilmington, Delaware. Likewise, in 2016, newly selected running mate Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia appeared with Hillary Clinton in Miami.\n\nAfter Tuesday's day trip to Pennsylvania, Harris and her running mate will spend the next five days flying thousands of miles around the country, touring critical battleground states. They'll visit Eau Claire, Wisconsin, and Detroit on Wednesday. But a planned stop in Savannah, Georgia, was postponed due to Tropical Storm Debby 's effects, and rain associated with it could also upend a scheduled stop in Durham, North Carolina.\n\nLater in the week, Harris and her No. 2 will head to Phoenix and Las Vegas.\n\nThat the schedule was set before her running mate was identified recalls a cliffhanger-like scenario that Trump created by holding off on making his choice of vice presidential hopeful, Ohio Sen. JD Vance, until last month's Republican National Convention was under way in Milwaukee.\n\nVance, meanwhile, is aiming to detract from the debut of Harris' pick on Tuesday. He planned to arrive in Philadelphia ahead of the Democratic ticket and offer his own speech at midday, as counterprogramming.\n\nThe senator then announced he'd shadow Harris and her running mate with his own events in Wisconsin, Michigan and North Carolina. It was unclear how the weather might affect his southern swing.\n\nIn announcing Vance's travels, the Trump campaign laid the blame for a litany of woes on Harris and Democratic policies, saying that \"prices are excruciatingly high, cost of living has soared, illegal immigrants are pouring into our country, and crime is running rampant. The stock market is crashing because of weak, failed, and dangerously liberal Kamala Harris' policies.\"\n\nHarris' campaign, for its part, welcomed the overlapping destinations.\n\n\"We appreciate JD Vance providing voters in battleground states exactly the split-screen that defines the choice this November,\" said Harris campaign spokesman Charles Lutvak.\n\nThe vice president's campaign says it has invited faith leaders, union members and state and local elected officials to participate in the upcoming events. Harris and her running mate plan to rally in a variety of venues, from large arenas to college campuses. The trip will also allow them to see voters in smaller settings like union halls, family owned restaurants and campaign field offices.\n\nAt a fundraiser in Minneapolis on Monday night, Walz said Trump has stolen America's joy and was limiting freedoms.\n\n\"It wasn't a slur to call these guys weird,\" Walz said of the label he has applied to the GOP ticket in recent days. \"It was an observation.\"\n\nIt's a characterization that has since taken off in Democratic circles.\n\nIf Harris opts for Shapiro, who hails from the Philadelphia suburbs, Tuesday's event with her there would be a homecoming of sorts.\n\nConsideration of Shapiro has drawn criticism from some Arab Americans and activist groups wary of his professed solidarity with Israel in its drive to eliminate Hamas during the war in Gaza. But Shapiro enjoys strong approval ratings in Pennsylvania -- one of the Democrats' crucial \"blue wall\" states along with Michigan and Wisconsin -- that Harris will be looking to cement ahead of November.\n\nOn a \"Progressives for Harris\" organizing call Monday night that organizers said drew tens of thousands of participants, speakers repeatedly derided Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as an \"authoritarian\" who was needlessly targeting and killing civilians in Gaza.\n\nSome delegates to the Democratic National Convention who supported \" uncommitted \" rather than Biden because of his administration's backing of Israel, also suggested that they weren't yet ready to support Harris until they knew more about her policies, including if she'll work more diligently toward a ceasefire in the Gaza fighting.\n\nBut those on the call refrained from criticizing Harris' potential running mates, instead focusing on Trump.\n\n\"Trump and JD Vance are promising more tax cuts for the mega-millionaires and billionaires,\" said Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren. \"This election is our chance to tax the rich and make the wealthy pay their fair share.\"\n\nAs for Kelly, some congressional Democrats have promoted the former astronaut whose state has more than 370 miles (600 kilometers) of border with Mexico. They say his selection could help defuse Trump's arguments that the Biden-Harris administration's immigration policies are too relaxed -- though some union leaders have suggested the senator isn't as US swing states", "body": "US Vice President and Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris has reportedly narrowed her VP pick to a choice between Josh Shapiro and Tim Walz\n\nKamala Harris was set to announce her running mate Tuesday before the pair head out on a five-day swing through America's hottest battleground states, just three months out from the presidential election.\n\nThe US vice president's campaign has come out of the blocks at a lightning pace since she replaced Joe Biden at the top of the Democratic ticket, smashing fundraising records and wiping out the leads built up by Republican rival Donald Trump.\n\nPennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro, a Democratic rising star, is considered the favorite to join Harris as her vice-presidential pick, ahead of several other state governors, a US senator and Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg.\n\nUS media reported Monday that Harris had narrowed one of the most consequential choices of her political career to Shapiro and Minnesota Governor Tim Walz and would likely make her decision public in a video announcement.\n\nLess than a day before their swing state journey, Harris was maintaining the suspense about her running mate, telling supporters in a text message Monday evening that \"I have not made my decision yet.\"\n\nHarris, 59, and her newly minted deputy will hold a rally Tuesday at Temple University in Philadelphia before hitting Wisconsin and Michigan on Wednesday, Arizona on Friday and Nevada on Saturday.\n\nShe was also intending to hold events in battlegrounds North Carolina on Thursday and Georgia on Friday, but local media outlets reported that a tropical storm battering southeastern states had forced their postponement. There was no response from the Harris campaign on a request for details.\n\nShapiro is enormously popular in Pennsylvania -- the largest of the six or seven swing states that have decided recent US elections -- and is seen as giving Harris a boost in what is considered must-win real estate for Democrats and Republicans alike.\n\nThe 51-year-old would be the country's first Jewish vice president, adding to the diversity of a ticket already boasting what would be the only woman ever sent to the Oval Office.\n\nHis support for Israel and handling of pro-Palestinian protests has sparked a leftist backlash, however, and Democrats are keen to ensure that their mid-August convention in Chicago isn't marred by progressive and anti-Israel activists.\n\n- Hard fight -\n\nShapiro's backers have argued in any case that the criticism is rooted in anti-Semitism, and many analysts believe his moderate profile gains him more votes from the center than it loses on the progressive fringe.\n\nThis combination of file pictures created on July 31, 2024 shows (L-R, top to bottom) US Vice President and Democratic Presidential candidate Kamala Harris in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, on July 23, 2024; and the five contenders being considered as her running mate Pennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro in Scranton, Pennsylvania, on April 16, 2024; Kentucky Governor Andy Beshear in Washington, DC, on April 26, 2023; Minnesota Governor Tim Walz in Washington, DC, on July 3, 2024; US Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona in Washington, DC, on May 4, 2024; US Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg in Washington, DC, on April 17, 2024. The Harris Presidential Campaign team announced on July 30, 2024, that the vice president and her new running mate would campaign next week in battlegrounds Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, Michigan, North Carolina, Georgia, Arizona and Nevada\n\nWalz, a 60-year-old former National Guard officer who exudes folksy charm, would bring a rural Midwestern perspective to the ticket but is seen as being from the liberal wing of the party.\n\nHe has been making a name for himself as one of the Democrats' most effective communicators in recent weeks, with his criticism of Trump and running mate J.D. Vance as \"weird\" gaining enormous traction.\n\nOther less likely contenders include Arizona Senator Mark Kelly, a former astronaut and war veteran; Kentucky Governor Andy Beshear, a longstanding friend of Harris; and Illinois Governor J.B. Pritzker.\n\nHarris threw her hat in the ring and began her search for a running mate after 81-year-old Biden exited the race on July 21.\n\nHe had been facing mounting concerns over his low popularity ratings and advanced years, and Trump was surging after surviving an assassination attempt and presiding over a united party at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee.\n\nMultiple recent polls have shown Harris's rise continuing unabated ever since, with a Morning Consult survey notably placing her four points ahead of Trump nationally, 48 to 44 percent.\n\nBut a new CBS News poll found Harris's popularity among Black voters some way behind Biden's score as he defeated Trump in 2020, prompting some senior Democrats to caution against complacency.\n\n\"She has a lot of momentum, but if you do look at the polling, this is still a really tight race,\" Barack Obama's one-time strategist David Axelrod told political outlet The Hill. \"This is going to be a hard fight for either side.\"", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Walz", "type": Vance after weeks of speculation and a bitter fight between candidates.\n\nThe 60-year-old father-of-two, who has been married to his teacher wife Gwen since 1994, joins the ticket in a victory for the far left of the party who were concerned about some of the other contenders' support of Israel.\n\nIn Minnesota Walz has codified the right to abortion, signed universal free school meals, legalized recreational marijuana and gave voting rights to former prisoners.\n\nThe former teacher is also credited with being the Democrat who started calling Republicans 'weird', a craze that has dominated the campaign since Joe Biden dropped out of the race last month.\n\nWalz turned the North Star State into a refuge for LGBTQ Americans and has also backed making Minnesota the 13th 'sanctuary' state for undocumented migrants.\n\nHarris announced her decision after a hotly-watched veepstakes in the two weeks after taking over Biden's campaign.\n\nPennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro and Arizona Sen. Mark Kelly were in the final three with Walz to run with Harris on November's Democratic ticket.\n\nKamala Harris has chosen Minnesota 's progressive governor Tim Walz as her running mate after weeks of speculation\n\nThe two are expected to be officially nominated as the president and vice presidential nominees at the Democratic National Convention Starting August 19 in Chicago.\n\nHarris earned enough support from delegates just two days after Biden announced he was ending his reelection bid.\n\nNow Walz will join Harris on Tuesday night for their first tandem campaign stop in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.\n\nHarris and Walz will head to the six other swing states for a five-day campaign blitz this week through Georgia, Michigan, Wisconsin, North Carolina, Nevada and Arizona.\n\nAfter growing up in a small Nebraska town he started teaching. First he went to China before moving to classrooms in Nebraska and Minnesota.\n\nIn Makato he taught geography and was the first faculty adviser for the school's first gay-straight alliance, set up in 1999.\n\nHe also coached the school's football team.\n\nWalz and his wife Gwen have two children together - Hope, who recently graduated from college in Montana, and Gus, who is in public high school in St. Paul, Minnesota.\n\nHe doesn't drink alcohol or coffee, he is a huge fan of Diet Mountain Dew and was arrested for DWI in Nebraska in 1995, before he quit drinking.\n\nTheir children were conceived by IVF and fertility treatments, a side of his story that can be used to attack Republicans on reproductive rights.\n\nAccording to the Star Tribune, Walz rides in the passenger seat on official duties because he gets carsick in the back.\n\nHe is also a runner, served in the Army National Guard and has hundreds of challenge coins he has collected in his office.\n\nWalz became governor of Minnesota in 2019 after serving six terms in the House of Representatives for the state's 1st congressional district, which encompasses its entire southern border.\n\nHe served as Democratic ranking member of the House Veterans' Affairs Committee for his final term before taking residence in the Minnesota Governor's Mansion in Saint Paul.\n\nGov. Walz takes a selfie with wife Gwen and their children Hope and Gus. They were both conceived through IVF and fertility treatment\n\nGov. Walz greets Vice President Kamala Harris at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport in Saint Paul, Minnesota on March 14, 2024\n\nWalz campaigns with his wife Gwena and daughter Hope. He doesn't drink alcohol or coffee, he is a huge fan of Diet Mountain Dew\n\nWalz is pictured with wife Gwen (center) and his children Hope (center right) and Gus (center left) as he is sworn in as Minnesota's governor in Saint Paul, Minnesota on January 7, 2019\n\nVice President Kamala Harris took over Joe Biden's 2024 campaign after the president ended his reelection bid and a few days later earned support from enough Democratic delegates to became the presumed nominee\n\nAlong with Shapiro and Kelly, there was a slew of speculation about others being considered for Harris' VP pick, including Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg, Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker and Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear.\n\nOn Monday afternoon, reporting emerged that Harris narrowed her decision to Shapiro and Walz.\n\nSome thought picking a running mate from a swing state would benefit Harris - like Shapiro from Pennsylvania or Arizona's Sen. Kelly.\n\nBut many leftists were worried that Shapiro, who is Jewish, would be too pro-Israel and Democrats were concerned it would re-spark controversial conversations about Gaza and hurt Harris' campaign.\n\nAlong with Shapiro and Kelly, there was a slew of speculation about others being considered for Harris' VP pick, including Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg, Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker and Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear.\n\nBut Walz's state of Minnesota is already solidly blue and voted for the Democratic candidates in 2016 and 2020.\n\nWalz is also a runner, served in the Army National Guard and has hundreds of challenge coins he has collected in his office\n\nIn Minnesota he has codified the right to abortion, signed universal free school meals, legalized recreational marijuana and gave voting rights to former prisoners\n\nGov. Walz and his wife Gwen greeted Biden in Northfield, Minnesota on Nov. 1, 2023\n\nMinnesota voted for Hillary Clinton 1.5 percent over Donald Trump and four years later widened the blue to red ratio by voting 7.1 percent for Biden over the former president.\n\nThe state is considered to be a 'lean Democrat' for the 2024 election, according to Cook Political Report.\n\nOn Monday afternoon, reporting {"uri": "8261877913", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "13:23:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T13:23:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:22:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://dailyprogress.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/harris-selects-minnesota-gov-tim-walz-as-running-mate-aiming-to-add-midwest-muscle/article_673ffd93-f5fb-596f-90d4-c230b2e75058.html", "title": "Harris selects Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz as running mate, aiming to add Midwest muscle", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Vice President Kamala Harris picked Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz to be her running mate on Tuesday, according to three people familiar with the decision.\n\nHarris wins Democratic nomination in virtual roll call. Here's how the process worked\n\nDemocratic delegates have selected Vice President Kamala Harris to be the party's presidential nominee. But don't expect a balloon drop just yet.\n\nIn choosing Walz, she is turning to a Midwestern governor, military veteran and union supporter who helped enact an ambitious Democratic agenda for his state, including sweeping protections for abortion rights and generous aid to families.\n\nHarris hopes to shore up her campaign's standing across the upper Midwest, a critical region in presidential politics that often serves as a buffer for Democrats seeking the White House. The party remains haunted by Republican Donald Trump's wins in Michigan and Wisconsin in 2016. Trump lost those states in 2020 but has zeroed in on them as he aims to return to the presidency this year and is expanding his focus to Minnesota.\n\nWalz, 60, is joining Harris during one of the most turbulent periods in modern American politics, promising an unpredictable campaign ahead. Republicans have rallied around Trump after his attempted assassination in July. Just weeks later, President Joe Biden ended his reelection campaign, forcing Harris to unify Democrats and consider potential running mates during an exceedingly compressed time frame.\n\nThe three people familiar with the decision spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because it had not been made public.\n\nHarris, the first Black woman and person of South Asian descent to lead a major party ticket, initially considered nearly a dozen candidates before zeroing in on a handful of serious contenders, all of whom were white men. In landing on Walz, she sided with a low-key partner who has proven himself as a champion for Democratic causes.\n\nElections Trump is making his 2024 campaign about Harris' race, whether Republicans want him to or not By STEVE PEOPLES and MATT BROWN Associated Press\n\nWalz has been a strong public advocate for Harris in her campaign against Trump and Vance, labeling the Republicans \"just weird\" in an interview last month. Democrats have seized on the message and amplified it since then.\n\nDuring a fundraiser for Harris on Monday in Minneapolis, Walz said: \"It wasn't a slur to call these guys weird. It was an observation.\"\n\nWalz, who grew up in the small town of West Point, Nebraska, was a social studies teacher, football coach and union member at Mankato West High School in Minnesota before he got into politics.\n\nHe won the first of six terms in Congress in 2006 from a mostly rural southern Minnesota district, and used the office to champion veterans issues. Walz served 24 years in the Army National Guard, rising to command sergeant major, one of the highest enlisted ranks in the military.\n\nHe ran for governor in 2018 on the theme of \"One Minnesota\" and won by more than 11 points.\n\nAs governor, Walz had to find ways to work in his first term with a legislature that was split between a Democratic-controlled House and a Republican-led Senate. Minnesota has a history of divided government, though, and the arrangement was surprisingly productive in his first year. But the COVID-19 pandemic hit Minnesota early in his second year, and bipartisan cooperation soon frayed.\n\nWalz relied on emergency powers to lead the state's response. Republicans chafed under restrictions that included lockdowns, closing schools and shuttering businesses. They retaliated by firing or forcing out some of his agency heads. But Minnesotans who were stuck at home also got to know Walz better through his frequent afternoon briefings in the early days of the crisis, which were broadcast and streamed statewide.\n\nWalz won reelection in 2022 by nearly 8 points over his GOP challenger, Dr. Scott Jensen, a physician and vaccine skeptic. Not only did Walz win, Democrats kept control of the House and flipped the Senate to win the \"trifecta\" of full control of both chambers and the governor's office for the first time in eight years. A big reason was the Supreme Court's Dobbs decision, which held that the Constitution doesn't include a right to abortion. That hurt Minnesota Republicans, especially among suburban women.\n\nGovernment-politics Civil Rights Movement Freedom Riders urge younger activists to get out the vote CHARLOTTE KRAMON Associated Press/Report for America\n\n\"Tim has been in the news because the country and the world is seeing the guy we love so much,\" U.S. Sen. Amy Klobuchar Klobuchar said Monday.\n\nKen Martin, Chairman of the Minnesota-Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party said young people he spoke to on the campaign trail were \"Walz pilled.\"\n\nWalz and other Democrats went into the 2023 legislative session with an ambitious agenda -- and a whopping $17.6 billion budget surplus to help fund it. Their proudest accomplishments included sweeping protections for abortion rights that included the elimination of nearly all restrictions Republicans had enacted in prior years, including a 24-hour waiting period and parental consent requirements. They also enacted new protections for trans rights, making the state a refuge for families coming from out of state for treatment for trans children.\n\nTheir other major accomplishments included tax credits for families with children that were aimed at slashing childhood poverty, as well as universal free school breakfasts and lunches for all students, regardless of family income. They also enacted a paid family and medical leave program, legalized recreational marijuana for adults and made it easier to vote.\n\nElections Donald Trump questions Kamala Harris' race as he appears at gathering of Black journalists By MATT BROWN and MICHELLE L. PRICE Associated Press\n\nRepublicans complained that Walz and his fellow Democrats squandered a surplus that would have been better spent on permanent tax relief for everyone. And they've faulted the governor and his administration for lax oversight of pandemic programs that cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars.\n\nFederal prosecutors charged 70 people with defrauding federal food programs that funded meals for kids during the pandemic out of $250 million on Walz's watch. Known as the Feeding Our Future scandal, it's one of the country's largest pandemic aid fraud cases. The Office of the Legislative Auditor, a nonpartisan watchdog, delivered a scathing report in June that said Walz's Department of Education \"failed to act on warning signs,\" did not effectively exercise its authority and was ill-prepared to respond.\n\nRepublicans still criticize Walz for his response to the sometimes violent unrest that followed the murder of George Floyd by a Minneapolis police officer in 2020, which included the torching of a police station.\n\nDuring a May fundraiser in St. Paul, Trump repeated his false claim that he was responsible for deploying the National Guard to quell the violence. \"The entire city was burning down. ... If you didn't have me as president, you wouldn't have Minneapolis today,\" Trump said.\n\nIt was actually Walz who gave the order, which he issued in response to requests from the mayors of Minneapolis and St. Paul. But within Minnesota, GOP legislators said both Walz and Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey were too slow to act. And there was finger-pointing between Frey and Walz on who was responsible for not activating the Guard faster.\n\nWalz has served often as a Biden-Harris surrogate, and has made increasingly frequent appearances on national television. They've included an interview on Fox News that irritated Trump so much that he posted on Truth Social, \"They make me fight battles I shouldn't have to fight.\" Walz is also co-chair of the rules committee for the Democratic National Convention. And he led a White House meeting of Democratic governors with Biden following the president's disastrous performance in his debate with Trump.\n\nElections Russia is relying on unwitting Americans to spread election disinformation, officials say DAVID KLEPPER Associated Press\n\nPutting Walz on the ticket could help Democrats hold the state's 10 electoral votes and bolster the party more broadly in the Midwest. No Republican has won a statewide race in Minnesota since Tim Pawlenty was re-elected governor in 2006, but GOP candidates for attorney general and state auditor came close in 2022.\n\nTrump finished just 1.5 percentage points behind Democrat Hillary Clinton in the state in 2016. While Biden carried Minnesota by more than 7 points in 2020, Trump has taken to falsely claiming that he won the state last time and can do it again.\n\nMinnesota has produced two vice presidents, Hubert Humphrey and Walter Mondale.\n\nPhotos: Kamala Harris through the years", "source": {"uri": "dailyprogress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Daily Progress"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8261877414", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "13:22:18", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T13:22:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:21:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/aug/06/harris-selects-minnesota-gov-tim-walz-as-running-m/", "title": "Harris selects Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz as running mate", "body": "Abbie Parr / Associated Press File (2022)\n\nMinnesota Gov. Tim Walz speaks to the media, Nov. 9, 2022, in St. Paul, Minn. Vice President Kamala Harris has picked Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz to be her running mate. Three people familiar with the decision confirmed the pick to The Associated Press on Tuesday.\n\nBy Seung Min Kim, Colleen Long, Zeke Miller and Will Weissert, The Associated Press\n\nTuesday, Aug. 6, 2024 | 6:10 a.m.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Vice President Kamala Harris picked Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz to be her running mate on Tuesday, according to three people familiar with the decision.\n\nIn choosing Walz, she is turning to a Midwestern governor, military veteran and union supporter who helped enact an ambitious Democratic agenda for his state, including sweeping protections for abortion rights and generous aid to families.\n\nHarris hopes to shore up her campaign's standing across the upper Midwest, a critical region in presidential politics that often serves as a buffer for Democrats seeking the White House. The party remains haunted by Republican Donald Trump's wins in Michigan and Wisconsin in 2016. Trump lost those states in 2020 but has zeroed in on them as he aims to return to the presidency this year and is expanding his focus to Minnesota.\n\nWalz, 60, is joining Harris during one of the most turbulent periods in modern American politics, promising an unpredictable campaign ahead. Republicans have rallied around Trump after his attempted assassination in July. Just weeks later, President Joe Biden ended his reelection campaign, forcing Harris to unify Democrats and consider potential running mates during an exceedingly compressed time frame.\n\nThe three people familiar with the decision spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because it had not been made public.\n\nHarris, the first Black woman and person of South Asian descent to lead a major party ticket, initially considered nearly a dozen candidates before zeroing in on a handful of serious contenders, all of whom were white men. In landing on Walz, she sided with a low-key partner who has proven himself as a champion for Democratic causes.\n\nWalz has been a strong public advocate for Harris in her campaign against Trump and Vance, labeling the Republicans \"just weird\" in an interview last month. Democrats have seized on the message and amplified it since then.\n\nDuring a fundraiser for Harris on Monday in Minneapolis, Walz said: \"It wasn't a slur to call these guys weird. It was an observation.\"\n\nWalz, who grew up in the small town of West Point, Nebraska, was a social studies teacher, football coach and union member at Mankato West High School in Minnesota before he got into politics.\n\nHe won the first of six terms in Congress in 2006 from a mostly rural southern Minnesota district, and used the office to champion veterans issues. Walz served 24 years in the Army National Guard, rising to command sergeant major, one of the highest enlisted ranks in the military.\n\nHe ran for governor in 2018 on the theme of \"One Minnesota\" and won by more than 11 points.\n\nAs governor, Walz had to find ways to work in his first term with a legislature that was split between a Democratic-controlled House and a Republican-led Senate. Minnesota has a history of divided government, though, and the arrangement was surprisingly productive in his first year. But the COVID-19 pandemic hit Minnesota early in his second year, and bipartisan cooperation soon frayed.\n\nWalz relied on emergency powers to lead the state's response. Republicans chafed under restrictions that included lockdowns, closing schools and shuttering businesses. They retaliated by firing or forcing out some of his agency heads. But Minnesotans who were stuck at home also got to know Walz better through his frequent afternoon briefings in the early days of the crisis, which were broadcast and streamed statewide.\n\nWalz won reelection in 2022 by nearly 8 points over his GOP challenger, Dr. Scott Jensen, a physician and vaccine skeptic. Not only did Walz win, Democrats kept control of the House and flipped the Senate to win the \"trifecta\" of full control of both chambers and the governor's office for the first time in eight years. A big reason was the Supreme Court's Dobbs decision, which held that the Constitution doesn't include a right to abortion. That hurt Minnesota Republicans, especially among suburban women.\n\n\"Tim has been in the news because the country and the world is seeing the guy we love so much,\" U.S. Sen. Amy Klobuchar Klobuchar said Monday.\n\nKen Martin, Chairman of the Minnesota-Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party said young people he spoke to on the campaign trail were \"Walz pilled.\"\n\nWalz and other Democrats went into the 2023 legislative session with an ambitious agenda -- and a whopping $17.6 billion budget surplus to help fund it. Their proudest accomplishments included sweeping protections for abortion rights that included the elimination of nearly all restrictions Republicans had enacted in prior years, including a 24-hour waiting period and parental consent requirements. They also enacted new protections for trans rights, making the state a refuge for families coming from out of state for treatment for trans children.\n\nTheir other major accomplishments included tax credits for families with children that were aimed at slashing childhood poverty, as well as universal free school breakfasts and lunches for all students, regardless of family income. They also enacted a paid family and medical leave program, legalized recreational marijuana for adults and made it easier to vote.\n\nRepublicans complained that Walz and his fellow Democrats squandered a surplus that would have been better spent on permanent tax relief for everyone. And they've faulted the governor and his administration for lax oversight of pandemic programs that cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars.\n\nFederal prosecutors charged 70 people with defrauding federal food programs that funded meals for kids during the pandemic out of $250 million on Walz's watch. Known as the Feeding Our Future scandal, it's one of the country's largest pandemic aid fraud cases. The Office of the Legislative Auditor, a nonpartisan watchdog, delivered a scathing report in June that said Walz's Department of Education \"failed to act on warning signs,\" did not effectively exercise its authority and was ill-prepared to respond.\n\nRepublicans still criticize Walz for his response to the sometimes violent unrest that followed the murder of George Floyd by a Minneapolis police officer in 2020, which included the torching of a police station.\n\nDuring a May fundraiser in St. Paul, Trump repeated his false claim that he was responsible for deploying the National Guard to quell the violence. \"The entire city was burning down. ... If you didn't have me as president, you wouldn't have Minneapolis today,\" Trump said.\n\nIt was actually Walz who gave the order, which he issued in response to requests from the mayors of Minneapolis and St. Paul. But within Minnesota, GOP legislators said both Walz and Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey were too slow to act. And there was finger-pointing between Frey and Walz on who was responsible for not activating the Guard faster.\n\nWalz has served often as a Biden-Harris surrogate, and has made increasingly frequent appearances on national television. They've included an interview on Fox News that irritated Trump so much that he posted on Truth Social, \"They make me fight battles I shouldn't have to fight.\" Walz is also co-chair of the rules committee for the Democratic National Convention. And he led a White House meeting of Democratic governors with Biden following the president's disastrous performance in his debate with Trump.\n\nPutting Walz on the ticket could help Democrats hold the state's 10 electoral votes and bolster the party more broadly in the Midwest. No Republican has won a statewide race in Minnesota since Tim Pawlenty was re-elected governor in 2006, but GOP candidates for attorney general and state auditor came close in 2022.\n\nTrump finished just 1.5 percentage points behind Democrat Hillary Clinton in the state in 2016. While Biden carried Minnesota by more than 7 points in 2020, Trump has taken to falsely claiming that he won the state last time and can do it again.\n\nMinnesota has produced two vice presidents, Josh Shapiro, Arizona Sen. Mark Kelly and Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, the Associated Press reported. It wasn't clear yet who she picked.\n\nIllinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker, Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear and U.S. Secretary of Department of Transportation Pete Buttigieg were have also been involved in the vetting process.\n\nThe expected announcement comes less than three weeks ahead of the Democratic National Convention in Chicago, scheduled for Aug. 19 through 22. Harris' running mate is expected to address the convention on Aug. 21, with the vice president taking the stage on Aug. 22. President Biden is also expected to speak at the event.\n\nMinnesota Gov. Tim Walz and Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro both met with Harris for one-on-one interviews Sunday according to NBC News, and are expected to be among the finalists to be on the presidential ticket this November, according to Reuters.\n\nArizona Sen. Mark Kelly also met with Harris on Sunday according to NBC News, and Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg met with her on Friday.\n\nSome congressional Democrats have promoted Kelly, a former Navy pilot and astronaut whose state has more than 370 miles or 600 kilometers of border with Mexico. They say his selection could help defuse Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's arguments that the Biden-Harris administration's immigration policies are too relaxed.\n\nShapiro has prominent supporters, too, like Philadelphia Mayor Cherelle Parker. She caused a stir by posting a video Friday depicting several Philadelphia-area officials and Democrats promoting Harris, but also playing up Shapiro as her running mate. A person familiar with the mayor's thinking said she had no insider knowledge about Harris' intentions.\n\nWhen asked about the veepstakes Monday, Shapiro said he had no information.\n\n\"I got nothing for you, man,\" he told an Associated Press reporter as he arrived at the Pennsylvania state capitol in Harrisburg. \"Have a great day.\"\n\nBoth Kelly and Shapiro have seen their detractors become more vocal as Harris closes in on a decision.\n\nWalz is in his second term as governor of Minnesota. He has made his state a bastion of liberal policy and, this year, one of the few states to protect fans buying tickets online for Taylor Swift concerts and other live events. He comes from rural America and in his first race for Congress, Walz upset a Republican incumbent.\n\nTrump's running mate, JD Vance, told Fox News on Sunday that Harris' pick doesn't matter to him. \"Whoever she chooses, the problem is going to be Kamala Harris' record and Kamala Harris' policies,\" he said, adding \"it's not going to be good for the country.\"\n\nThe Democratic National Convention kicks off in Chicago Monday, Aug. 19 at the United Center. "image": "https://assets.zerohedge.com/s3fs-public/styles/16_9_max_700/public/2024-08/unnamed.png?itok=6RKk527m", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9788903", "eventUri": "eng-9788903", {"uri": "8261882845", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "13:26:29", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T13:26:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:25:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics/harris-selects-minnesota-gov-tim-walz-as-running-mate-midwesterner-known-for-union-support-and-family-aid", "title": "Harris selects Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz as running mate, Midwesterner known for union support and family aid", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Vice President Kamala Harris picked Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz to be her running mate on Tuesday, according to three people familiar with the decision.\n\nIn choosing Walz, she is turning to a Midwestern governor, military veteran and union supporter who helped enact an ambitious Democratic agenda for his state, including sweeping protections for abortion rights and generous aid to families.\n\nREAD MORE: Before Harris' VP pick, how Americans feel about possible running mates\n\nHarris hopes to shore up her campaign's standing across the upper Midwest, a critical region in presidential politics that often serves as a buffer for Democrats seeking the White House. The party remains haunted by Republican Donald Trump's wins in Michigan and Wisconsin in 2016. Trump lost those states in 2020 but has zeroed in on them as he aims to return to the presidency this year and is expanding his focus to Minnesota.\n\nWalz, 60, is joining Harris during one of the most turbulent periods in modern American politics, promising an unpredictable campaign ahead. Republicans have rallied around Trump after his attempted assassination in July. Just weeks later, President Joe Biden ended his reelection campaign, forcing Harris to unify Democrats and consider potential running mates during an exceedingly compressed time frame.\n\nThe three people familiar with the decision spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because it had not been made public.\n\nHarris, the first Black woman and person of South Asian descent to lead a major party ticket, initially considered nearly a dozen candidates before zeroing in on a handful of serious contenders, all of whom were white men. In landing on Walz, she sided with a low-key partner who has proven himself as a champion for Democratic causes.\n\nWalz has been a strong public advocate for Harris in her campaign against Trump and Vance, labeling the Republicans \"just weird\" in an interview last month. Democrats have seized on the message and amplified it since then.\n\nDuring a fundraiser for Harris on Monday in Minneapolis, Walz said: \"It wasn't a slur to call these guys weird. It was an observation.\"\n\nWalz, who grew up in the small town of West Point, Nebraska, was a social studies teacher, football coach and union member at Mankato West High School in Minnesota before he got into politics.\n\nHe won the first of six terms in Congress in 2006 from a mostly rural southern Minnesota district, and used the office to champion veterans issues. Walz served 24 years in the Army National Guard, rising to command sergeant major, one of the highest enlisted ranks in the military.\n\nHe ran for governor in 2018 on the theme of \"One Minnesota\" and won by more than 11 points.\n\nAs governor, Walz had to find ways to work in his first term with a legislature that was split between a Democratic-controlled House and a Republican-led Senate. Minnesota has a history of divided government, though, and the arrangement was surprisingly productive in his first year. But the COVID-19 pandemic hit Minnesota early in his second year, and bipartisan cooperation soon frayed.\n\nWalz relied on emergency powers to lead the state's response. Republicans chafed under restrictions that included lockdowns, closing schools and shuttering businesses. They retaliated by firing or forcing out some of his agency heads. But Minnesotans who were stuck at home also got to know Walz better through his frequent afternoon briefings in the early days of the crisis, which were broadcast and streamed statewide.\n\nWalz won reelection in 2022 by nearly 8 points over his GOP challenger, Dr. Scott Jensen, a physician and vaccine skeptic. Not only did Walz win, Democrats kept control of the House and flipped the Senate to win the \"trifecta\" of full control of both chambers and the governor's office for the first time in eight years. A big reason was the Supreme Court's Dobbs decision, which held that the Constitution doesn't include a right to abortion. That hurt Minnesota Republicans, especially among suburban women.\n\n\"Tim has been in the news because the country and the world is seeing the guy we love so much,\" U.S. Sen. Amy Klobuchar Klobuchar said Monday.\n\nKen Martin, Chairman of the Minnesota-Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party said young people he spoke to on the campaign trail were \"Walz pilled.\"\n\nWalz and other Democrats went into the 2023 legislative session with an ambitious agenda -- and a whopping $17.6 billion budget surplus to help fund it. Their proudest accomplishments included sweeping protections for abortion rights that included the elimination of nearly all restrictions Republicans had enacted in prior years, including a 24-hour waiting period and parental consent requirements. They also enacted new protections for trans rights, making the state a refuge for families coming from out of state for treatment for trans children.\n\nTheir other major accomplishments included tax credits for families with children that were aimed at slashing childhood poverty, as well as universal free school breakfasts and lunches for all students, regardless of family income. They also enacted a paid family and medical leave program, legalized recreational marijuana for adults and made it easier to vote.\n\nREAD MORE: Rally venues and dates are set, the only thing missing for Harris' campaign blitz is her VP pick\n\nRepublicans complained that Walz and his fellow Democrats squandered a surplus that would have been better spent on permanent tax relief for everyone. And they've faulted the governor and his administration for lax oversight of pandemic programs that cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars.\n\nFederal prosecutors charged 70 people with defrauding federal food programs that funded meals for kids during the pandemic out of $250 million on Walz's watch. Known as the Feeding Our Future scandal, it's one of the country's largest pandemic aid fraud cases. The Office of the Legislative Auditor, a nonpartisan watchdog, delivered a scathing report in June that said Walz's Department of Education \"failed to act on warning signs,\" did not effectively exercise its authority and was ill-prepared to respond.\n\nRepublicans still criticize Walz for his response to the sometimes violent unrest that followed the murder of George Floyd by a Minneapolis police officer in 2020, which included the torching of a police station.\n\nDuring a May fundraiser in St. Paul, Trump repeated his false claim that he was responsible for deploying the National Guard to quell the violence. \"The entire city was burning down. ... If you didn't have me as president, you wouldn't have Minneapolis today,\" Trump said.\n\nIt was actually Walz who gave the order, which he issued in response to requests from the mayors of Minneapolis and St. Paul. But within Minnesota, GOP legislators said both Walz and Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey were too slow to act. And there was finger-pointing between Frey and Walz on who was responsible for not activating the Guard faster.\n\nWalz has served often as a Biden-Harris surrogate, and has made increasingly frequent appearances on national television. They've included an interview on Fox News that irritated Trump so much that he posted on Truth Social, \"They make me fight battles I shouldn't have to fight.\" Walz is also co-chair of the rules committee for the Democratic National Convention. And he led a White House meeting of Democratic governors with Biden following the president's disastrous performance in his debate with Trump.\n\nPutting Walz on the ticket could help Democrats hold the state's 10 electoral votes and bolster the party more broadly in the Midwest. No Republican has won a statewide race in Minnesota since Tim Pawlenty was re-elected governor in 2006, but GOP candidates for attorney general and state auditor came close in 2022.\n\nTrump finished just 1.5 percentage points behind Democrat Hillary Clinton in the state in 2016. While Biden carried Minnesota by more than 7 points in 2020, Trump has taken to falsely claiming that he won the state last time and can do it again.\n\nMinnesota has produced two vice presidents, Hubert Humphrey and Walter Mondale.", "source": {"uri": "pbs.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "PBS.org"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@pbs.org", "name": "Associated Press", "type": {"uri": "8261671487", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "11:14:13", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T11:14:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T11:13:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/us-politics/article-democratic-nominee-kamala-harris-to-introduce-new-running-mate-at/", "title": "Democratic nominee Kamala Harris to introduce new running mate at Philadelphia rally", "body": "Vice-President Kamala Harris will introduce her new running mate at a rally Tuesday evening in Philadelphia - but with the event mere hours away, her choice remains a mystery.\n\nIn recent days, she has zeroed in on a trio of potential finalists: Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro, Arizona Sen. Mark Kelly and Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, but decisions beyond that aren't yet publicly known.\n\nHarris' campaign planned to make the announcement via video message before the rally, though the exact timing remained unclear, according to a person involved in the planning who spoke on the condition of anonymity to detail discussions occurring behind closed doors.\n\nDoing so would be similar to how then-candidate Joe Biden revealed Harris as his vice-presidential choice during the pandemic-marred presidential race of 2020.\n\nIt will mark yet another major milestone in the barely two weeks since the vice-president moved to take over the top of the Democratic ticket heading into November's election. She has been scrambling to build out a campaign since then, and to breathe new life into the Democratic race against Republican Donald Trump.\n\nHarris, second gentleman Doug Emhoff and her No. 2 pick are set to appear together for an evening rally in Philadelphia, recalling a joint 2020 appearance by Biden and Harris in Wilmington, Delaware. Likewise, in 2016, newly selected running mate Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia appeared with Hillary Clinton in Miami.\n\nAfter Tuesday's day trip to Pennsylvania, Harris and her running mate will spend the next five days flying thousands of miles around the country, touring critical battleground states. They'll visit Eau Claire, Wisconsin, and Detroit on Wednesday. But a planned stop in Savannah, Georgia, was postponed due to Tropical Storm Debby 's effects, and rain associated with it could also upend a scheduled stop in Durham, North Carolina.\n\nLater in the week, Harris and her No. 2 will head to Phoenix and Las Vegas.\n\nThat the schedule was set before her running mate was identified recalls a cliffhanger-like scenario that Trump created by holding off on making his choice of vice-presidential hopeful, Ohio Sen. JD Vance, until last month's Republican National Convention was under way in Milwaukee.\n\nVance, meanwhile, is aiming to detract from the debut of Harris' pick on Tuesday. He planned to arrive in Philadelphia ahead of the Democratic ticket and offer his own speech at midday, as counterprogramming.\n\nThe senator then announced he'd shadow Harris and her running mate with his own events in Wisconsin, Michigan and North Carolina. It was unclear how the weather might affect his southern swing.\n\nIn announcing Vance's travels, the Trump campaign laid the blame for a litany of woes on Harris and Democratic policies, saying that \"prices are excruciatingly high, cost of living has soared, illegal immigrants are pouring into our country, and crime is running rampant. The stock market is crashing because of weak, failed, and dangerously liberal Kamala Harris' policies.\"\n\nHarris' campaign, for its part, welcomed the overlapping destinations.\n\n\"We appreciate JD Vance providing voters in battleground states exactly the split-screen that defines the choice this November,\" said Harris campaign spokesman Charles Lutvak.\n\nThe vice-president's campaign says it has invited faith leaders, union members and state and local elected officials to participate in the upcoming events. Harris and her running mate plan to rally in a variety of venues, from large arenas to college campuses. The trip will also allow them to see voters in smaller settings like union halls, family owned restaurants and campaign field offices.\n\nAt a fundraiser in Minneapolis on Monday night, Walz said Trump has stolen America's joy and was limiting freedoms.\n\n\"It wasn't a slur to call these guys weird,\" Walz said of the label he has applied to the GOP ticket in recent days. \"It was an observation.\"\n\nIt's a characterization that has since taken off in Democratic circles.\n\nIf Harris opts for Shapiro, who hails from the Philadelphia suburbs, Tuesday's event with her there would be a homecoming of sorts.\n\nConsideration of Shapiro has drawn criticism from some Arab Americans and activist groups wary of his professed solidarity with Israel in its drive to eliminate Hamas during the war in Gaza. But Shapiro enjoys strong approval ratings in Pennsylvania - one of the Democrats' crucial \"blue wall\" states along with Michigan and Wisconsin - that Harris will be looking to cement ahead of November.\n\nOn a \"Progressives for Harris\" organizing call Monday night that organizers said drew tens of thousands of participants, speakers repeatedly derided Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as an \"authoritarian\" who was needlessly targeting and killing civilians in Gaza.\n\nSome delegates to the Democratic National Convention who supported \" uncommitted \" rather than Biden because of his administration's backing of Israel, also suggested that they weren't yet ready to support Harris until they knew more about her policies, including if she'll work more diligently toward a ceasefire in the Gaza fighting.\n\nBut those on the call refrained from criticizing Harris' potential running mates, instead focusing on Trump.\n\n\"Trump and JD Vance are promising more tax cuts for the mega-millionaires and billionaires,\" said Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren. \"This election is our chance to tax the rich and make the wealthy pay their fair share.\"\n\nAs for Kelly, some congressional Democrats have promoted the former astronaut whose state has more than 370 miles (600 kilometers) of border with Mexico. They say his selection could help defuse Trump's arguments that the Biden-Harris administration's immigration policies are too relaxed - though some union leaders have suggested the senator isn't as friendly to organized labor as they'd like.", "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Globe and Mail"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": advantage in key Rust Belt states like Wisconsin, Michigan, and Pennsylvania, which are crucial for securing the 270 electoral votes needed for a Democratic victory.\n\nThis sets the stage for a fall
