{"uri": "8261847150", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "13:04:35", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T13:04:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:03:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.daytondailynews.com/nation-world/harris-has-decided-on-a-running-mate-ap-sources-say-an-announcement-is-expected-tuesday/UJ3MH6A35ZAEFLSTLNINIIE56U/", "title": "Harris selects Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz as running mate, aiming to add Midwest muscle to ticket", "body": "In choosing Walz, she is turning to a Midwestern governor, military veteran and union supporter who helped enact an ambitious Democratic agenda for his state, including sweeping protections for abortion rights and generous aid to families.\n\nHarris hopes to shore up her campaign's standing across the upper Midwest, a critical region in presidential politics that often serves as a buffer for Democrats seeking the White House. The party remains haunted by Republican Donald Trump's wins in Michigan and Wisconsin in 2016. Trump lost those states in 2020 but has zeroed in on them as he aims to return to the presidency this year and is expanding his focus to Minnesota.\n\nWalz, 60, is joining Harris during one of the most turbulent periods in modern American politics, promising an unpredictable campaign ahead. Republicans have rallied around Trump after his attempted assassination in July. Just weeks later, President Joe Biden ended his reelection campaign, forcing Harris to unify Democrats and consider potential running mates during an exceedingly compressed time frame.\n\nThe three people spoke on condition of anonymity to avoid preempting the official announcenment later Tuesday.\n\nHarris, the first Black woman and person of South Asian descent to lead a major party ticket, initially considered nearly a dozen candidates before zeroing in on a handful of serious contenders, all of whom were white men. In landing on Walz, she sided with a low-key partner who has proven himself as a champion for Democratic causes.\n\nWalz has been a strong public advocate for Harris in her campaign against Trump and Vance, labeling the Republicans \"just weird\" in an interview last month. Democrats have seized on the message and amplified it since then.\n\nDuring a fundraiser for Harris on Monday in Minneapolis, Walz said: \"It wasn't a slur to call these guys weird. It was an observation.\"\n\nWalz, who grew up in the small town of West Point, Nebraska, was a social studies teacher, football coach and union member at Mankato West High School in Minnesota before he got into politics.\n\nHe won the first of six terms in Congress in 2006 from a mostly rural southern Minnesota district, and used the office to champion veterans issues. Walz served 24 years in the Army National Guard, rising to command sergeant major, one of the highest enlisted ranks in the military.\n\nHe ran for governor in 2018 on the theme of \"One Minnesota\" and won by more than 11 points.\n\nAs governor, Walz had to find ways to work in his first term with a legislature that was split between a Democratic-controlled House and a Republican-led Senate. Minnesota has a history of divided government, though, and the arrangement was surprisingly productive in his first year. But the COVID-19 pandemic hit Minnesota early in his second year, and bipartisan cooperation soon frayed.\n\nWalz relied on emergency powers to lead the state's response. Republicans chafed under restrictions that included lockdowns, closing schools and shuttering businesses. They retaliated by firing or forcing out some of his agency heads. But Minnesotans who were stuck at home also got to know Walz better through his frequent afternoon briefings in the early days of the crisis, which were broadcast and streamed statewide.\n\nWalz won reelection in 2022 by nearly 8 points over his GOP challenger, Dr. Scott Jensen, a physician and vaccine skeptic. Not only did Walz win, Democrats kept control of the House and flipped the Senate to win the \"trifecta\" of full control of both chambers and the governor's office for the first time in eight years. A big reason was the Supreme Court's Dobbs decision, which held that the Constitution doesn't include a right to abortion. That hurt Minnesota Republicans, especially among suburban women.\n\n\"Tim has been in the news because the country and the world is seeing the guy we love so much,\" U.S. Sen. Amy Klobuchar Klobuchar said Monday.\n\nKen Martin, Chairman of the Minnesota-Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party said young people he spoke to on the campaign trail were \"Walz pilled.\"\n\nWalz and other Democrats went into the 2023 legislative session with an ambitious agenda -- and a whopping $17.6 billion budget surplus to help fund it. Their proudest accomplishments included sweeping protections for abortion rights that included the elimination of nearly all restrictions Republicans had enacted in prior years, including a 24-hour waiting period and parental consent requirements. They also enacted new protections for trans rights, making the state a refuge for families coming from out of state for treatment for trans children.\n\nTheir other major accomplishments included tax credits for families with children that were aimed at slashing childhood poverty, as well as universal free school breakfasts and lunches for all students, regardless of family income. They also enacted a paid family and medical leave program, legalized recreational marijuana for adults and made it easier to vote.\n\nRepublicans complained that Walz and his fellow Democrats squandered a surplus that would have been better spent on permanent tax relief for everyone. And they've faulted the governor and his administration for lax oversight of pandemic programs that cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars.\n\nFederal prosecutors charged 70 people with defrauding federal food programs that funded meals for kids during the pandemic out of $250 million on Walz's watch. Known as the Feeding Our Future scandal, it's one of the country's largest pandemic aid fraud cases. The Office of the Legislative Auditor, a nonpartisan watchdog, delivered a scathing report in June that said Walz's Department of Education \"failed to act on warning signs,\" did not effectively exercise its authority and was ill-prepared to respond.\n\nRepublicans still criticize Walz for his response to the sometimes violent unrest that followed the murder of George Floyd by a Minneapolis police officer in 2020, which included the torching of a police station.\n\nDuring a May fundraiser in St. Paul, Trump repeated his false claim that he was responsible for deploying the National Guard to quell the violence. \"The entire city was burning down. ... If you didn't have me as president, you wouldn't have Minneapolis today,\" Trump said.\n\nIt was actually Walz who gave the order, which he issued in response to requests from the mayors of Minneapolis and St. Paul. But within Minnesota, GOP legislators said both Walz and Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey were too slow to act. And there was finger-pointing between Frey and Walz on who was responsible for not activating the Guard faster.\n\nWalz has served often as a Biden-Harris surrogate, and has made increasingly frequent appearances on national television. They've included an interview on Fox News that irritated Trump so much that he posted on Truth Social, \"They make me fight battles I shouldn't have to fight.\" Walz is also co-chair of the rules committee for the Democratic National Convention. And he led a White House meeting of Democratic governors with Biden following the president's disastrous performance in his debate with Trump.\n\nPutting Walz on the ticket could help Democrats hold the state's 10 electoral votes and bolster the party more broadly in the Midwest. No Republican has won a statewide race in Minnesota since Tim Pawlenty was re-elected governor in 2006, but GOP candidates for attorney general and state auditor came close in 2022.\n\nTrump finished just 1.5 percentage points behind Democrat Hillary Clinton in the state in 2016. While Biden carried Minnesota by more than 7 points in 2020, Trump has taken to falsely claiming that he won the state last time and can do it again.", "source": {"uri": "daytondailynews.com", {"uri": "8261870665", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "13:18:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T13:18:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:17:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/harris-selects-minnesota-gov-tim-walz-as-running-mate-aiming-to-add-midwest-muscle/article_6eae2d0f-b618-54ef-9401-366494da6693.html", "title": "Harris selects Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz as running mate, aiming to add Midwest muscle", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Vice President Kamala Harris picked Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz to be her running mate on Tuesday, according to three people familiar with the decision.\n\nHarris wins Democratic nomination in virtual roll call. Here's how the process worked By ROBERT YOON - Associated Press\n\nIn choosing Walz, she is turning to a Midwestern governor, military veteran and union supporter who helped enact an ambitious Democratic agenda for his state, including sweeping protections for abortion rights and generous aid to families.\n\nHarris hopes to shore up her campaign's standing across the upper Midwest, a critical region in presidential politics that often serves as a buffer for Democrats seeking the White House. The party remains haunted by Republican Donald Trump's wins in Michigan and Wisconsin in 2016. Trump lost those states in 2020 but has zeroed in on them as he aims to return to the presidency this year and is expanding his focus to Minnesota.\n\nPeople are also reading... VHSL PRESEASON FOOTBALL PRIMER: Plenty of storylines as prep football begins in Virginia HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Not yet 30, Norris achieves goal as Lebanon head coach Antiques showcased at Virginia Highlands Festival HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL | Trust and obey: Former Sullivan East star Laisure now playing for Science Hill Hilltoppers PREP BASKETBALL: Field released for The Classic at Tennessee High Platter & Pour working to open State Street location OLYMPICS: Johnson City-born Brody Malone helps U.S. get bronze in men's gymnastics team competition HIGH SCHOOL NOTEBOOK: Wise Central's Emmah McAmis on Under Armour national title team; Some transfers and new coaching hires as well LOCAL MOTORSPORTS: Chilhowie racer knows the Bristol Motor Speedway experience Harshbarger defeats Lundberg in heated state senate race PREP SPORTS: VHSL leaders hold public meeting in Abingdon HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL: Hart steps down at Honaker, not seeing commitment in offseason The Big Tri City Fair looks to bring fun and entertainment HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Viking football just means more to Tennessee High's Trent Dowdell MLB: Rangers outfielder Evan Carter (Elizabethton) likely to miss rest of regular season with back injury\n\nWalz, 60, is joining Harris during one of the most turbulent periods in modern American politics, promising an unpredictable campaign ahead. Republicans have rallied around Trump after his attempted assassination in July. Just weeks later, President Joe Biden ended his reelection campaign, forcing Harris to unify Democrats and consider potential running mates during an exceedingly compressed time frame.\n\nThe three people familiar with the decision spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because it had not been made public.\n\nHarris, the first Black woman and person of South Asian descent to lead a major party ticket, initially considered nearly a dozen candidates before zeroing in on a handful of serious contenders, all of whom were white men. In landing on Walz, she sided with a low-key partner who has proven himself as a champion for Democratic causes.\n\nElections Trump is making his 2024 campaign about Harris' race, whether Republicans want him to or not By STEVE PEOPLES and MATT BROWN Associated Press\n\nWalz has been a strong public advocate for Harris in her campaign against Trump and Vance, labeling the Republicans \"just weird\" in an interview last month. Democrats have seized on the message and amplified it since then.\n\nDuring a fundraiser for Harris on Monday in Minneapolis, Walz said: \"It wasn't a slur to call these guys weird. It was an observation.\"\n\nWalz, who grew up in the small town of West Point, Nebraska, was a social studies teacher, football coach and union member at Mankato West High School in Minnesota before he got into politics.\n\nHe won the first of six terms in Congress in 2006 from a mostly rural southern Minnesota district, and used the office to champion veterans issues. Walz served 24 years in the Army National Guard, rising to command sergeant major, one of the highest enlisted ranks in the military.\n\nHe ran for governor in 2018 on the theme of \"One Minnesota\" and won by more than 11 points.\n\nAs governor, Walz had to find ways to work in his first term with a legislature that was split between a Democratic-controlled House and a Republican-led Senate. Minnesota has a history of divided government, though, and the arrangement was surprisingly productive in his first year. But the COVID-19 pandemic hit Minnesota early in his second year, and bipartisan cooperation soon frayed.\n\nWalz relied on emergency powers to lead the state's response. Republicans chafed under restrictions that included lockdowns, closing schools and shuttering businesses. They retaliated by firing or forcing out some of his agency heads. But Minnesotans who were stuck at home also got to know Walz better through his frequent afternoon briefings in the early days of the crisis, which were broadcast and streamed statewide.\n\nWalz won reelection in 2022 by nearly 8 points over his GOP challenger, Dr. Scott Jensen, a physician and vaccine skeptic. Not only did Walz win, Democrats kept control of the House and flipped the Senate to win the \"trifecta\" of full control of both chambers and the governor's office for the first time in eight years. A big reason was the Supreme Court's Dobbs decision, which held that the Constitution doesn't include a right to abortion. That hurt Minnesota Republicans, especially among suburban women.\n\nCrime-courts Civil Rights Movement Freedom Riders urge younger activists to get out the vote CHARLOTTE KRAMON Associated Press/Report for America\n\n\"Tim has been in the news because the country and the world is seeing the guy we love so much,\" U.S. Sen. Amy Klobuchar Klobuchar said Monday.\n\nKen Martin, Chairman of the Minnesota-Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party said young people he spoke to on the campaign trail were \"Walz pilled.\"\n\nWalz and other Democrats went into the 2023 legislative session with an ambitious agenda -- and a whopping $17.6 billion budget surplus to help fund it. Their proudest accomplishments included sweeping protections for abortion rights that included the elimination of nearly all restrictions Republicans had enacted in prior years, including a 24-hour waiting period and parental consent requirements. They also enacted new protections for trans rights, making the state a refuge for families coming from out of state for treatment for trans children.\n\nTheir other major accomplishments included tax credits for families with children that were aimed at slashing childhood poverty, as well as universal free school breakfasts and lunches for all students, regardless of family income. They also enacted a paid family and medical leave program, legalized recreational marijuana for adults and made it easier to vote.\n\nElections Donald Trump questions Kamala Harris' race as he appears at gathering of Black journalists By MATT BROWN and MICHELLE L. PRICE Associated Press\n\nRepublicans complained that Walz and his fellow Democrats squandered a surplus that would have been better spent on permanent tax relief for everyone. And they've faulted the governor and his administration for lax oversight of pandemic programs that cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars.\n\nFederal prosecutors charged 70 people with defrauding federal food programs that funded meals for kids during the pandemic out of $250 million on Walz's watch. Known as the Feeding Our Future scandal, it's one of the country's largest pandemic aid fraud cases. The Office of the Legislative Auditor, a nonpartisan watchdog, delivered a scathing report in June that said Walz's Department of Education \"failed to act on warning signs,\" did not effectively exercise its authority and was ill-prepared to respond.\n\nRepublicans still criticize Walz for his response to the sometimes violent unrest that followed the murder of George Floyd by a Minneapolis police officer in 2020, which included the torching of a police station.\n\nDuring a May fundraiser in St. Paul, Trump repeated his false claim that he was responsible for deploying the National Guard to quell the violence. \"The entire city was burning down. ... If you didn't have me as president, you wouldn't have Minneapolis today,\" Trump said.\n\nIt was actually Walz who gave the order, which he issued in response to requests from the mayors of Minneapolis and St. Paul. But within Minnesota, GOP legislators said both Walz and Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey were too slow to act. And there was finger-pointing between Frey and Walz on who was responsible for not activating the Guard faster.\n\nWalz has served often as a Biden-Harris surrogate, and has made increasingly frequent appearances on national television. They've included an interview on Fox News that irritated Trump so much that he posted on Truth Social, \"They make me fight battles I shouldn't have to fight.\" Walz is also co-chair of the rules committee for the Democratic National Convention. And he led a White House meeting of Democratic governors with Biden following the president's disastrous performance in his debate with Trump.\n\nElections Russia is relying on unwitting Americans to spread election disinformation, officials say DAVID KLEPPER Associated Press\n\nPutting Walz on the ticket could help Democrats hold the state's 10 electoral votes and bolster the party more broadly in the Midwest. No Republican has won a statewide race in Minnesota since Tim Pawlenty was re-elected governor in 2006, but GOP candidates for attorney general and state auditor came close in 2022.\n\nTrump finished just 1.5 percentage points behind Democrat Hillary Clinton in the state in 2016. While Biden carried Minnesota by more than 7 points in 2020, Trump has taken to falsely claiming that he won the state last time and can do it again.\n\nMinnesota has produced two vice presidents, Hubert Humphrey and Walter Mondale.\n\nPhotos: Kamala Harris through the years Get Government & Politics updates in your inbox!\n\nStay up-to-date on the latest in local and national government and political topics with our newsletter.\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": She will reveal her vice presidential running mate on Tuesday in her first major decision as the Democratic Party's presidential candidate.\n\nHarris, who is the first woman and first Black and South Asian person to serve as vice president, has narrowed her list of candidates to Pennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro and Minnesota Governor Tim Walz, sources told Reuters on Monday, after considering a field of finalists made up of white men with a record of winning over rural, white or independent voters.\n\nAfter President Joe Biden withdrew from his re-election campaign earlier this month, Harris emerged as the Democratic Party's candidate. Since taking on this role, she has successfully raised hundreds of millions of dollars and reinvigorated the race against Republican Donald Trump with increased enthusiasm from her party's supporters.\n\nALSO READ: US Court Rules On Google's Dominance In Online Search Market; Here's What Tech Giant Said\n\nAlthough she had gathered enough delegates to be her party's nominee, the Democratic National Committee said late on Monday that she had officially secured the nomination.", "source": {"uri": "english.jagran.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Jagran English"}, "authors": {"uri": "8261813689", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "12:42:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T12:42:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T12:42:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://penncapital-star.com/election-2024/kamala-harris-to-campaign-with-her-running-mate-pennsylvania-philadelphia/", "title": "Kamala Harris to campaign with her running mate in Philadelphia * Pennsylvania Capital-Star", "body": "PHILADELPHIA -- Vice President Kamala Harris and her running mate will appear together in Philadelphia today at a rally on Temple University's campus, the first time Harris is visiting Pennsylvania as the Democrats' presumptive nominee for president. It's been less than a month since Harris' last visit to the City of Brotherly Love, but in that time she's gone from being President Joe Biden's running mate to leading at the top of the ticket.\n\nThe speculation about Harris' running mate reached a fever pitch on Monday, with observers looking for any clue about who her pick would be. Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro is believed to be one of the finalists for the job, along with Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz and U.S. Sen. Mark Kelly of Arizona. Shapiro's public schedule for Tuesday shows he will \"deliver remarks at the Harris for President event at Temple University\" at 5 p.m., which doesn't necessarily confirm whether he will get the VP nod.\n\n\"The Harris campaign is taking nothing for granted in Pennsylvania,\" Harris Pennsylvania campaign communications director Jack Doyle said Tuesday. \"We have built a massive campaign infrastructure in Pennsylvania, and we're harnessing the energy we're seeing on the ground to persuade and mobilize the voters who will decide this election.\"\n\nThe month of July began with Biden trailing in the polls after a poor debate performance in late June raised concerns about whether he could beat GOP nominee Donald Trump. Two days before the Republican National Convention, a gunman shot at Trump during a rally in Butler, killing one rally-goer and injuring two others. The following weekend, Biden bowed out of the race and immediately endorsed Harris, with Democrats quickly coalescing behind her candidacy.\n\nLate Monday, the Democratic National Committee announced Harris had secured the support of 99% of delegates to formally become the party's presidential nominee, following the conclusion of a five-day virtual vote. She is expected to formally accept the nomination at the Democratic National Convention later this month.\n\nThe Biden-Harris campaign raised $284.1 million between January 2023 and June 30, 2024, while Trump's campaign raised $217.2 million during that time period. Trump entered July with $128.1 million on hand, while Biden's campaign had $96 million on hand.\n\nBut Harris raised $310 million in July according to her campaign, while Trump's campaign said it raised $138 million.\n\nTrump campaigns in Harrisburg in first trip back to Pennsylvania since assassination attempt\n\nAnd although the election is still less than three months away, Pennsylvanians are already being inundated with ads and will continue to be throughout the campaign. AdImpact data showed that Trump and Harris are slated to spend more than twice as much on advertising in Pennsylvania as any of the other pivotal battleground states.\n\nPrior to Biden's exit from the race, Trump was consistently polling slightly ahead of Biden in Pennsylvania. However, since Harris emerged as the presumptive nominee, some polling shows the race in a statistical tie.\n\nTuesday will be Harris' seventh visit to Pennsylvania this year, according to the campaign. Her most recent appearance in the commonwealth was on July 13 in Philadelphia to court Asian-American voters. She's also campaigned this cycle in Pittsburgh to tout the administration's infrastructure investments, in Philadelphia to talk student debt with educators, and in Montgomery County to speak in support of reproductive rights. Harris has been the Biden administration's primary voice on abortion rights, particularly in the aftermath of the U.S. Supreme Court's Dobbs decision that overturned Roe v. Wade\n\nAnd in case anyone doubted Philadelphia's importance in the 2024 race, U.S. Sen. J.D. Vance (R-Ohio), Trump's running mate, will be in Philadelphia on Tuesday as well, for his first campaign event in Pennsylvania\n\nTrump was most recently in the state last Wednesday for an indoor rally in Harrisburg, his first campaign stop in the Keystone State since the assassination attempt.\n\nHarris's campaign swing with her running mate begins in Pennsylvania, then she's scheduled to campaign in other key battleground states Wisconsin, Michigan, North Carolina, Georgia, Arizona and Nevada over the next few days. Trump and Vance are also slated to make appearances in key battleground states later this week.", "source": {"uri": "penncapital-star.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Pennsylvania Capital-Star"}, vice-presidential pick for US election", "body": "Several people close to the process say she had made her choice.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris has made a decision on her running mate, with four people close to the process saying Governor Tim Walz of Minnesota is her choice.\n\nHarris had not formally called Walz to offer him the position, a source familiar with the process told CNN.\n\nA as running mate' in US presidential election", "body": "In choosing Mr Walz, she is turning to a Midwestern governor, military veteran and union supporter who helped enact an ambitious Democratic agenda for his state, including sweeping protections for abortion rights and generous aid to families.\n\nMs Harris hopes to shore up her campaign's standing across the upper Midwest, a critical region in presidential politics that often serves as a buffer for Democrats seeking the White House.\n\nThe party remains haunted by Republican Donald Trump's wins in Michigan and Wisconsin in 2016.\n\nMr Trump lost those states in 2020, but has zeroed in on them as he aims to return to the presidency this year and is expanding his focus to Minnesota.\n\nMr Walz, 60, is joining Ms Harris during one of the most turbulent periods in modern American politics, promising an unpredictable campaign ahead.\n\nRepublicans have rallied around Mr Trump after his attempted assassination in July.\n\nJust weeks later, President Joe Biden ended his re-election campaign, forcing Ms Harris to unify Democrats and consider potential running mates during an exceedingly compressed time frame.\n\nThe three people spoke on condition of anonymity to avoid pre-empting the official announcement later on Tuesday.\n\nMs Harris, the first Black woman and person of South Asian descent to lead a major party ticket, initially considered nearly a dozen candidates before zeroing in on a handful of serious contenders, all of whom were white men.\n\nIn landing on Mr Walz, she sided with a low-key partner who has proven himself as a champion for Democratic causes.\n\nMr Walz has been a strong public advocate for Ms Harris in her campaign against Mr Trump and Mr Vance, labelling the Republicans \"just weird\" in an interview last month.\n\nDemocrats have seized on the message and amplified it since then.\n\nDuring a fundraiser for Ms Harris on Monday in Minneapolis, Mr Walz said: \"It wasn't a slur to call these guys weird. It was an observation.\"\n\nMr Walz, who grew up in the small town of West Point, Nebraska, was a social studies teacher, football coach and union member at Mankato West High School in Minnesota before he got into politics.\n\nHe won the first of six terms in Congress in 2006 from a mostly rural southern Minnesota district, and used the office to champion veterans issues.\n\nMr Walz served 24 years in the Army National Guard, rising to command sergeant major, one of the highest enlisted ranks in the military.\n\nHe has often served as a Biden-Harris surrogate, and has made increasingly frequent appearances on national television.\n\nThey have included an interview on Fox News that irritated Mr Trump so much that he posted on Truth Social: \"They make me fight battles I shouldn't have to fight.\"\n\nPutting Mr Walz on the ticket could help Democrats hold the state's 10 electoral votes and bolster the party more broadly in the Midwest.\n\nNo Republican has won a state-wide race in Minnesota since Tim Pawlenty was re-elected governor in 2006, but GOP candidates for attorney general and state auditor came close in 2022.\n\nMr Trump finished just 1.5 percentage points behind Democrat Hillary Clinton in the state in 2016.\n\nWhile Mr Biden carried Minnesota by more than seven points in 2020, Mr Trump has taken to falsely claiming that he won the state last time and can do Each PredictIt bet sells for between 1\u00a2 and 99\u00a2 depending on its probability, with the customer then getting $1 if the answer they guess is correct.\n\nHowever, as of 5 a.m. ET, Shapiro had retaken the lead on the platform, with a bet on the Pennsylvania governor completing the 2024 Democratic Party ticket selling at 53\u00a2 ahead of Walz on 50\u00a2, Beshear and Kelly with 3\u00a2 each, and 1\u00a2 for Buttigieg. The PredictIt website is run out of Victoria University of Wellington, New Zealand.\n\nThere has been widespread speculation over who Harris would pick as her running mate since she became the Democrats' presumptive presidential nominee shortly after President Joe Biden dropped out of the 2024 race and endorsed her. On August 5, Politico reported Harris will announce her vice-presidential selection on Tuesday ahead of a rally she is due to attend in Philadelphia in the evening.\n\nAt 5 a.m. ET on Tuesday, U.K.-based bookmaker William Hill offered odds of 8/11 (57.9 percent) on Shapiro being the 2024 Democratic vice-presidential nominee, ahead of Walz on 47.6 percent with no other candidate on more than three percent. Separately, betting website Betfair gave odds of 1/2 (66.7 percent) on Shapiro being picked, with Walz in second place on 11/8 (42.1 percent).\n\nNewsweek contacted Governor Walz's press office and representatives of Vice President Kamala Harris for comment on Tuesday by email outside of regular office hours.\n\nReuters on Monday reported that Harris had narrowed her vice-presidential shortlist down to just two candidates, Governors Walz and Shapiro.\n\nIn a message to supporters, urging them to sign up so they would receive her VP announcement, Harris on Monday said she hadn't made her final decision. She said: \"I know many of you are eager to find out who I will be selecting to join me on the campaign trail, and hopefully in the White House, as my Vice President.\n\n\"Though I have not made my decision yet, it is important to me that grassroots supporters -- like you -- have direct updates about the state of the race.\"\n\nSpeaking to Newsweek, Thomas Gift, a political scientist who heads the Centre on U.S. Politics at University College London, U.K., said selecting Shapiro as her running mate would put the key swing state of Pennsylvania \"in play\" for Harris.\n\nHe said: \"While most polling has shown Trump leading Pennsylvania by a nontrivial margin, Harris picking Shapiro puts PA's 19 electoral votes in play -- pure and simple...Even if Trump wins Pennsylvania, selecting Shapiro would force him to expend significantly more resources in the Keystone State to do it, siphoning off valuable cash and energy from other battleground states.\"\n\nA poll of 1,510 likely voters He has steered Minnesota toward liberal policies including guaranteeing abortion rights, requiring paid family leave and incentivizing affordable housing.\n\nWalz's stance on Israel\n\nWalz traveled to Israel on a 2009 diplomatic trip to the Middle East during which he met with both Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Syrian President Bashar al-Asad.\n\nIn Congress, he voted with the {"uri": "8261860277", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "13:11:50", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T13:11:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:11:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/world/united-states/harris-selects-minnesota-gov-tim-walz-as-running-mate-aiming-to-add-midwest-muscle-to/article_db1b313e-2b46-576d-86cc-4ffc03d7ecd7.html", "title": "Harris selects Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz as running mate, aiming to add Midwest muscle to ticket", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Vice President Kamala Harris picked Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz to be her running mate on Tuesday, according to three people familiar with the decision.\n\nIn choosing Walz, she is turning to a Midwestern governor, military veteran and union supporter who helped enact an ambitious Democratic agenda for his state, including sweeping protections for abortion rights and generous aid to families.\n\nHarris hopes to shore up her campaign's standing across the upper Midwest, a critical region in presidential politics that often serves as a buffer for Democrats seeking the White House. The party remains haunted by Republican Donald Trump's wins in Michigan and Wisconsin in 2016. Trump lost those states in 2020 but has zeroed in on them as he aims to return to the presidency this year and is expanding his focus to Minnesota.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nWalz, 60, is joining Harris during one of the most turbulent periods in modern American politics, promising an unpredictable campaign ahead. Republicans have rallied around Trump after his attempted assassination in July. Just weeks later, President Joe Biden ended his reelection campaign, forcing Harris to unify Democrats and consider potential running mates during an exceedingly compressed time frame.\n\nThe three people familiar with the decision spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because it had not been made public.\n\nHarris, the first Black woman and person of South Asian descent to lead a major party ticket, initially considered nearly a dozen candidates before zeroing in on a handful of serious contenders, all of whom were white men. In landing on Walz, she sided with a low-key partner who has proven himself as a champion for Democratic causes.\n\nWalz has been a strong public advocate for Harris in her campaign against Trump and Vance, labeling the Republicans \"just weird\" in an interview last month. Democrats have seized on the message and amplified it since then.\n\nDuring a fundraiser for Harris on Monday in Minneapolis, Walz said: \"It wasn't a slur to call these guys weird. It was an observation.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nWalz, who grew up in the small town of West Point, Nebraska, was a social studies teacher, football coach and union member at Mankato West High School in Minnesota before he got into politics.\n\nHe won the first of six terms in Congress in 2006 from a mostly rural southern Minnesota district, and used the office to champion veterans issues. Walz served 24 years in the Army National Guard, rising to command sergeant major, one of the highest enlisted ranks in the military.\n\nHe ran for governor in 2018 on the theme of \"One Minnesota\" and won by more than 11 points.\n\nAs governor, Walz had to find ways to work in his first term with a legislature that was split between a Democratic-controlled House and a Republican-led Senate. Minnesota has a history of divided government, though, and the arrangement was surprisingly productive in his first year. But the COVID-19 pandemic hit Minnesota early in his second year, and bipartisan cooperation soon frayed.\n\nWalz relied on emergency powers to lead the state's response. Republicans chafed under restrictions that included lockdowns, closing schools and shuttering businesses. They retaliated by firing or forcing out some of his agency heads. But Minnesotans who were stuck at home also got to know Walz better through his frequent afternoon briefings in the early days of the crisis, which were broadcast and streamed statewide.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nWalz won reelection in 2022 by nearly 8 points over his GOP challenger, Dr. Scott Jensen, a physician and vaccine skeptic. Not only did Walz win, Democrats kept control of the House and flipped the Senate to win the \"trifecta\" of full control of both chambers and the governor's office for the first time in eight years. A big reason was the Supreme Court's Dobbs decision, which held that the Constitution doesn't include a right to abortion. That hurt Minnesota Republicans, especially among suburban women.\n\n\"Tim has been in the news because the country and the world is seeing the guy we love so much,\" U.S. Sen. Amy Klobuchar Klobuchar said Monday.\n\nKen Martin, Chairman of the Minnesota-Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party said young people he spoke to on the campaign trail were \"Walz pilled.\"\n\nWalz and other Democrats went into the 2023 legislative session with an ambitious agenda -- and a whopping $17.6 billion budget surplus to help fund it. Their proudest accomplishments included sweeping protections for abortion rights that included the elimination of nearly all restrictions Republicans had enacted in prior years, including a 24-hour waiting period and parental consent requirements. They also enacted new protections for trans rights, making the state a refuge for families coming from out of state for treatment for trans children.\n\nTheir other major accomplishments included tax credits for families with children that were aimed at slashing childhood poverty, as well as universal free school breakfasts and lunches for all students, regardless of family income. They also enacted a paid family and medical leave program, legalized recreational marijuana for adults and made it easier to vote.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nRepublicans complained that Walz and his fellow Democrats squandered a surplus that would have been better spent on permanent tax relief for everyone. And they've faulted the governor and his administration for lax oversight of pandemic programs that cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars.\n\nFederal prosecutors charged 70 people with defrauding federal food programs that funded meals for kids during the pandemic out of $250 million on Walz's watch. Known as the Feeding Our Future scandal, it's one of the country's largest pandemic aid fraud cases. The Office of the Legislative Auditor, a nonpartisan watchdog, delivered a scathing report in June that said Walz's Department of Education \"failed to act on warning signs,\" did not effectively exercise its authority and was ill-prepared to respond.\n\nRepublicans still criticize Walz for his response to the sometimes violent unrest that followed the murder of George Floyd by a Minneapolis police officer in 2020, which included the torching of a police station.\n\nDuring a May fundraiser in St. Paul, Trump repeated his false claim that he was responsible for deploying the National Guard to quell the violence. \"The entire city was burning down. ... If you didn't have me as president, you wouldn't have Minneapolis today,\" Trump said.\n\nIt was actually Walz who gave the order, which he issued in response to requests from the mayors of Minneapolis and St. Paul. But within Minnesota, GOP legislators said both Walz and Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey were too slow to act. And there was finger-pointing between Frey and Walz on who was responsible for not activating the Guard faster.\n\nWalz has served often as a Biden-Harris surrogate, and has made increasingly frequent appearances on national television. They've included an interview on Fox News that irritated Trump so much that he posted on Truth Social, \"They make me fight battles I shouldn't have to fight.\" Walz is also co-chair of the rules committee for the Democratic National Convention. And he led a White House meeting of Democratic governors with Biden following the president's disastrous performance in his debate with Trump.\n\nPutting Walz on the ticket could help Democrats hold the state's 10 electoral votes and bolster the party more broadly in the Midwest. No Republican has won a statewide race in Minnesota since Tim Pawlenty was re-elected governor in 2006, but GOP candidates for attorney general and state auditor came close in 2022.\n\nTrump finished just 1.5 percentage points behind Democrat Hillary Clinton in the state in 2016. While Biden carried Minnesota by more than 7 points in 2020, Trump has taken to falsely claiming that he won the state last time and can do it again.\n\nMinnesota has produced two vice presidents, Hubert Humphrey and Walter Mondale.", "source": {"uri": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8261863231", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "13:14:08", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T13:14:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:13:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.euronews.com/2024/08/06/kamala-harris-chooses-minnesota-governor-tim-walz-as-running-mate", "title": "Kamala Harris chooses Minnesota Governor Tim Walz as running mate", "body": "The Democrats, whose national convention begins in two weeks, are working hard to shore themselves up in an expanding number of swing states.\n\nUS Vice President Kamala Harris has selected Minnesota Governor Tim Walz to be her running mate in this year's presidential election, according to multiple sources.\n\nHarris and Walz will appear together for the first time at a rally this afternoon in Philadelphia, the largest city in the key swing state of Pennsylvania -- whose own governor, Josh Shapiro, was also a finalist in Harris's search for a partner.\n\nWalz, a relatively moderate Democrat who is popular in his home state, only came to broad national attention over the last two weeks as Harris vetted various candidates, many of whom experienced an uptick in media attention as their names were mentioned.\n\nHarris's choice comes two weeks ahead of the Democratic National Convention in Chicago, where she and Walz will formally accept their nominations as the party's candidates.\n\nSince sitting US President Joe Biden dropped his re-election bid on 21 July and immediately endorsed her as his successor, Harris has been met with an unexpectedly euphoric reception from Democratic-leaning voters.\n\nMonths of sluggish polling and fundraising under Biden have given way to surges on both fronts. Harris now leads or matches former President and Republican candidate Donald Trump in most national and swing state polls, and her campaign has pulled in record sums of money in its first fortnight.\n\nOf the $310 million (\u20ac284 million) raised in July, $200m (\u20ac183m) was donated in the week after her candidacy was announced.\n\nMeanwhile, Trump and his Republican colleagues have struggled to formulate a coherent message against Harris.\n\nWhile many of the former president's outriders have tried to blame her for the Biden administration's policy on the US-Mexico border, Trump himself has caused a furore with remarks in which he accused the biracial vice president of \"turning black\".\n\nHis running mate, Ohio Senator JD Vance, has also attracted outrage and derision for past remarks about women -- in particular, a resurfaced interview in which he blamed those who are not raising children for the supposed decline of the US.\n\n\"We are effectively run in this country via the Democrats, via our corporate oligarchs, by a bunch of childless cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives and the choices that they've made,\" Vance told Fox News in 2021, \"and {"uri": "8261866296", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "13:15:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T13:15:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:14:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/campaigns/presidential/3102857/kamala-harris-tim-walz-vice-presidential-pick/", "title": "Vice President Kamala Harris chooses Tim Walz to be her running mate - Washington Examiner", "body": "Vice President Kamala Harris has chosen Gov. Tim Walz (D-MN) to be her running mate, fewer than 100 days before the 2024 election and four years to the week that President Joe Biden tapped her to become his No. 2.\n\nHarris's choice, confirmed by the Associated Press, caps a truncated vetting process after Democrats quickly coalesced behind Harris as their replacement nominee last month after Biden suspended his reelection campaign in response to party pressure to step aside over concerns about his age, mental acuity, and electoral prospects against former President Donald Trump.\n\nHarris's decision sets a tone for her campaign and potential administration.\n\nAlmost a dozen vice presidential candidates were reportedly vetted by former President Barack Obama Attorney General Eric Holder and one-time Biden White House counsel Dana Remus, but the top three contenders became Walz, Govs. Josh Shapiro (D-PA), and Sen. Mark Kelly (D-AZ), after Gov. Roy Cooper (D-NC) withdrew his name from consideration. Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg, as well as Govs. Andy Beshear (D-KY) and J.B. Pritzker (D-IL), were also said to be interviewed by Harris's vetting team and the vice president herself.\n\nHarris's calculus was reportedly predicated on whether the presumptive vice presidential nominee could help her win before helping her govern, with the desire to avoid negative press like that generated by Sen. J.D. Vance (R-OH) for the Trump campaign over his \"childless cat ladies\" comments. Harris's husband second gentleman Doug Emhoff and brother-in-law Tony West, who worked under Holder at the Obama Justice Department, were trusted advisers throughout.\n\nThose supporting Shapiro, 51, who became Pennsylvania's governor in 2023 after serving as the commonwealth's attorney general since 2017, contended he could help Harris win the Keystone State, whose 19 Electoral College votes will likely decide the contest. Harris can win Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, and Wisconsin, but will still not have the 270 electoral votes needed for the presidency.\n\nShapiro, who is Jewish, encountered a \"No Genocide Josh\" protest to his vice presidential candidacy, despite having similar policy positions related to the Israel-Hamas war as the other contenders. He was additionally criticized for his lack of leadership after a 2018 sexual harassment complaint was made against a former aide. The staffer was on Shapiro's payroll until last September when he resigned after the matter was settled.\n\nSimilarly to Shapiro, proponents of Kelly, 60, a former astronaut and Navy captain who was first elected to Congress in 2020, argued he could help Harris put Arizona back in play after Biden's slippage with minority voters and on issues, including the economy and the border, in the Grand Canyon State. Kelly's wife, ex-Rep. Gabrielle Giffords, almost died in a shooting during a constituent event in 2011, with the couple founding the gun control advocacy and research organization, Giffords, in the aftermath. Kelly came under scrutiny for Chinese venture capital investment in the spy balloon company he started and his delay in supporting the pro-labor union PRO Act.\n\nWalz, 60, a former Army National Guardsman and social studies teacher before he ran for the House of Representatives in 2006, was thought to bring executive experience rather than a battleground state, having been Minnesota's governor since 2018. Folksy Midwestern Walz, who was favored by Biden, House Speaker Emeritus Nancy Pelosi, and United Auto Workers President Shawn Fain, was behind the Harris campaign beginning to undermine Trump and Vance as \"weird,\" with comparisons drawn between him and Sen. Tim Kaine (D-VA), 2016 Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton's running mate.\n\nThe same arguments were made for Cooper, 67, himself a two-term, term-limited governor. Cooper had the advantage of having a pre-existing relationship with Harris from when he was North Carolina's attorney general and she was his Californian counterpart. North Carolina was the state Trump won by the smallest margin over Biden in 2020 and the Harris campaign has projected confidence about it, regardless of polling that suggests otherwise.\n\n\"This just wasn't the right time for North Carolina and for me to potentially be on a national ticket,\" Cooper posted on social media.\n\nHarris and her vice presidential pick will now embark on a five-day, seven-state battleground tour, scheduled to kick-off in Philadelphia on Tuesday night, to introduce themselves to the public and underscore what is at stake this election. He already has a Harris campaign chief of staff in Liz Allen, who was most recently the State Department's Assistant Secretary for Global Public Affairs.\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE WASHINGTON EXAMINER\n\n\"In addition to holding rallies in each location along the tour, at venues ranging from big arenas to college campuses, including HBCUs, the vice president and her running mate will also take the time to meet with voters in smaller, more intimate settings, including union halls, family-owned restaurants, campaign field offices, and more,\" Harris campaign spokeswoman Lauren Hitt wrote in a statement. \"These stops will highlight the ticket's strength in the blue wall and Sunbelt, from urban areas to rural communities. At each stop, our new ticket will be joined by local elected officials, union members, faith leaders, and more.\"\n\nHarris announced her presidential understudy before an Aug. 7 deadline, two weeks before this cycle's Democratic National Convention, after a political fight with Ohio's Republican-controlled legislature over the Buckeye State's ballot access laws. Although Gov. Mike DeWine (R-OH) signed legislation extending the state's deadline so Biden and then Harris could appear on its ballots, Democrats have remained adamant Ohio Secretary of State Frank LaRose, a Trump ally, could cause problems and held a virtual roll call vote instead during the last week.", "source": {"uri": "washingtonexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Examiner"}, "authors": {"uri": "8261864996", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "13:15:05", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T13:15:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:14:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/harris-selects-minnesota-gov-tim-walz-as-running-mate-aiming-to-add-midwest-muscle-to/article_5effb8a4-31e9-517a-8da2-a46083bcaf38.html", "title": "Harris selects Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz as running mate, aiming to add Midwest muscle to ticket", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Vice President Kamala Harris picked Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz to be her running mate on Tuesday, according to three people familiar with the decision.\n\nHarris wins Democratic nomination in virtual roll call. Here's how the process worked By ROBERT YOON - Associated Press\n\nIn choosing Walz, she is turning to a Midwestern governor, military veteran and union supporter who helped enact an ambitious Democratic agenda for his state, including sweeping protections for abortion rights and generous aid to families.\n\nHarris hopes to shore up her campaign's standing across the upper Midwest, a critical region in presidential politics that often serves as a buffer for Democrats seeking the White House. The party remains haunted by Republican Donald Trump's wins in Michigan and Wisconsin in 2016. Trump lost those states in 2020 but has zeroed in on them as he aims to return to the presidency this year and is expanding his focus to Minnesota.\n\nPeople are also reading... Tom and Molly Bedell's West Lake Okoboji home sells for state record $9.5M 'We'll miss the place': Home on Sioux City's north side on market for first time in decades A shellfish guest: Chesapeake blue crab found at Sioux City Library Sierra signage going up at former Sioux City Bed Bath & Beyond Sioux City's original guitar hero to be celebrated with a three-night musical extravaganza Olympic Athletics Results: USD's Chris Nilsen finishes 11th in pole vault group Police release name of man pulled from Floyd River Toast on Hill offering classy breakfast and lunch to Okoboji Lakes visitors A favorite Sioux City deli stages a comeback with a new lobby and full menu of sandwiches Simon Max Kaplan Fireworks serve as weekly grand finale for Arnolds Park's Saturday night concert series Sioux City schools vandalized with graffiti over weekend Sioux City Council to vote on resolution for faith-based treatment center City of Sioux City issues guidance for tree limb disposal Marriage licenses for August 5, 2024\n\nWalz, 60, is joining Harris during one of the most turbulent periods in modern American politics, promising an unpredictable campaign ahead. Republicans have rallied around Trump after his attempted assassination in July. Just weeks later, President Joe Biden ended his reelection campaign, forcing Harris to unify Democrats and consider potential running mates during an exceedingly compressed time frame.\n\nThe three people familiar with the decision spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because it had not been made public.\n\nHarris, the first Black woman and person of South Asian descent to lead a major party ticket, initially considered nearly a dozen candidates before zeroing in on a handful of serious contenders, all of whom were white men. In landing on Walz, she sided with a low-key partner who has proven himself as a champion for Democratic causes.\n\nElections Trump is making his 2024 campaign about Harris' race, whether Republicans want him to or not By STEVE PEOPLES and MATT BROWN Associated Press\n\nWalz has been a strong public advocate for Harris in her campaign against Trump and Vance, labeling the Republicans \"just weird\" in an interview last month. Democrats have seized on the message and amplified it since then.\n\nDuring a fundraiser for Harris on Monday in Minneapolis, Walz said: \"It wasn't a slur to call these guys weird. It was an observation.\"\n\nWalz, who grew up in the small town of West Point, Nebraska, was a social studies teacher, football coach and union member at Mankato West High School in Minnesota before he got into politics.\n\nHe won the first of six terms in Congress in 2006 from a mostly rural southern Minnesota district, and used the office to champion veterans issues. Walz served 24 years in the Army National Guard, rising to command sergeant major, one of the highest enlisted ranks in the military.\n\nHe ran for governor in 2018 on the theme of \"One Minnesota\" and won by more than 11 points.\n\nAs governor, Walz had to find ways to work in his first term with a legislature that was split between a Democratic-controlled House and a Republican-led Senate. Minnesota has a history of divided government, though, and the arrangement was surprisingly productive in his first year. But the COVID-19 pandemic hit Minnesota early in his second year, and bipartisan cooperation soon frayed.\n\nWalz relied on emergency powers to lead the state's response. Republicans chafed under restrictions that included lockdowns, closing schools and shuttering businesses. They retaliated by firing or forcing out some of his agency heads. But Minnesotans who were stuck at home also got to know Walz better through his frequent afternoon briefings in the early days of the crisis, which were broadcast and streamed statewide.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nWalz won reelection in 2022 by nearly 8 points over his GOP challenger, Dr. Scott Jensen, a physician and vaccine skeptic. Not only did Walz win, Democrats kept control of the House and flipped the Senate to win the \"trifecta\" of full control of both chambers and the governor's office for the first time in eight years. A big reason was the Supreme Court's Dobbs decision, which held that the Constitution doesn't include a right to abortion. That hurt Minnesota Republicans, especially among suburban women.\n\nCrime-courts Civil Rights Movement Freedom Riders urge younger activists to get out the vote CHARLOTTE KRAMON Associated Press/Report for America\n\n\"Tim has been in the news because the country and the world is seeing the guy we love so much,\" U.S. Sen. Amy Klobuchar Klobuchar said Monday.\n\nKen Martin, Chairman of the Minnesota-Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party said young people he spoke to on the campaign trail were \"Walz pilled.\"\n\nWalz and other Democrats went into the 2023 legislative session with an ambitious agenda -- and a whopping $17.6 billion budget surplus to help fund it. Their proudest accomplishments included sweeping protections for abortion rights that included the elimination of nearly all restrictions Republicans had enacted in prior years, including a 24-hour waiting period and parental consent requirements. They also enacted new protections for trans rights, making the state a refuge for families coming from out of state for treatment for trans children.\n\nTheir other major accomplishments included tax credits for families with children that were aimed at slashing childhood poverty, as well as universal free school breakfasts and lunches for all students, regardless of family income. They also enacted a paid family and medical leave program, legalized recreational marijuana for adults and made it easier to vote.\n\nElections Donald Trump questions Kamala Harris' race as he appears at gathering of Black journalists By MATT BROWN and MICHELLE L. PRICE Associated Press\n\nRepublicans complained that Walz and his fellow Democrats squandered a surplus that would have been better spent on permanent tax relief for everyone. And they've faulted the governor and his administration for lax oversight of pandemic programs that cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars.\n\nFederal prosecutors charged 70 people with defrauding federal food programs that funded meals for kids during the pandemic out of $250 million on Walz's watch. Known as the Feeding Our Future scandal, it's one of the country's largest pandemic aid fraud cases. The Office of the Legislative Auditor, a nonpartisan watchdog, delivered a scathing report in June that said Walz's Department of Education \"failed to act on warning signs,\" did not effectively exercise its authority and was ill-prepared to respond.\n\nRepublicans still criticize Walz for his response to the sometimes violent unrest that followed the murder of George Floyd by a Minneapolis police officer in 2020, which included the torching of a police station.\n\nDuring a May fundraiser in St. Paul, Trump repeated his false claim that he was responsible for deploying the National Guard to quell the violence. \"The entire city was burning down. ... If you didn't have me as president, you wouldn't have Minneapolis today,\" Trump said.\n\nIt was actually Walz who gave the order, which he issued in response to requests from the mayors of Minneapolis and St. Paul. But within Minnesota, GOP legislators said both Walz and Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey were too slow to act. And there was finger-pointing between Frey and Walz on who was responsible for not activating the Guard faster.\n\nWalz has served often as a Biden-Harris surrogate, and has made increasingly frequent appearances on national television. They've included an interview on Fox News that irritated Trump so much that he posted on Truth Social, \"They make me fight battles I shouldn't have to fight.\" Walz is also co-chair of the rules committee for the Democratic National Convention. And he led a White House meeting of Democratic governors with Biden following the president's disastrous performance in his debate with Trump.\n\nElections Russia is relying on unwitting Americans to spread election disinformation, officials say DAVID KLEPPER Associated Press\n\nPutting Walz on the ticket could help Democrats hold the state's 10 electoral votes and bolster the party more broadly in the Midwest. No Republican has won a statewide race in Minnesota since Tim Pawlenty was re-elected governor in 2006, but GOP candidates for attorney general and state auditor came close in 2022.\n\nTrump finished just 1.5 percentage points behind Democrat Hillary Clinton in the state in 2016. While Biden carried Minnesota by more than 7 points in 2020, Trump has taken to falsely claiming that he won the state last time and can do it again.\n\nMinnesota has produced two vice presidents, Hubert Humphrey and Walter Mondale.\n\nPhotos: Kamala Harris through the years 0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nGet Government & Politics updates in your inbox!\n\nStay up-to-date on She officially claimed the nomination Monday night when the DNC released final results.\n\nSources say Harris has decided on a running mate\n\nVice President Kamala Harris has decided on a running mate and an announcement is expected in the coming hours before the two appear together at a Philadelphia rally, according to three people familiar with her decision.\n\nIn recent days, she has zeroed in on a trio of potential finalists: Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro, Arizona Sen. Mark Kelly and Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz. It wasn't clear yet who she picked.\n\nThe people were familiar with her plans but spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity to discuss a decision that had not been publicly {"uri": "8261874565", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "13:21:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T13:21:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:20:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/meet-tim-walz-harris-vp-131709618.html", "title": "Meet Tim Walz, Harris' VP Pick Who First Called Trump Weird", "body": "Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz is a true dark horse: an unassuming, nerdy former high school teacher, military veteran and politician who is, gosh darnit, a nice guy.\n\nFew ordinary Americans outside his home state had ever heard of him, much less considered him vice presidential material, until he helped pivot the Democratic messaging against Donald Trump from \"threat to democracy\" to plain old \"weird.\"\n\nOne thing he shares in common with J.D. Vance: Walz loves a good old (diet) Mountain Dew, his drink of choice after he gave up alcohol following a DUI in 1995.\n\nChosen by Kamala Harris Tuesday morning to be her running mate on the Democratic presidential ticket, Walz, 60, was the highest-ranking enlisted soldier to serve in Congress, he was a member of the House of Representatives for a dozen years before his successful run for governor in 2018.\n\nWalz brings a rural, Midwestern -- \"Minnesota nice\" -- sensibility to the Democratic ticket as Harris and Walz blast off on a five-day tour of must-win battleground states, starting Tuesday evening in Philadelphia.\n\nWalz can also go toe-to-toe with Donald Trump's running mate on a key issue for Democrats in the 2024 election: reproductive rights. Especially after Vance's slight against Democrats like Harris as \"childless cat ladies.\"\n\nHe and his wife of three decades, Gwen Whipple, opened up about their struggle with infertility after the Alabama Supreme Court ruled earlier this year that embryos created through in vitro fertilization should be considered children, jeopardizing the legality of IVF across the country. They have two children, Hope, a recent college graduate, and Gus, who is in high school.\n\nWalz shot into the spotlight last month after he coined the viral label \"weird\" for Trump and Vance. Fans fawned over his Midwestern \"BDE\" dad vibes.\n\nThe new vice presidential aspirant steered his state's response to COVID-19, police reform following the murder of George Floyd in Minneapolis and a slew of progressive legislative achievements, including legalization of marijuana and paid family leave.\n\nRead more at The Daily Beast.\n\nGet the Daily Beast's biggest scoops and scandals delivered right to your inbox. {"uri": "2024-08-443120505", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "20:27:50", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T20:27:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T20:23:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/4809450-bernie-sanders-kamala-harris-tim-walz-veepstakes-2024-election/", "title": "Sanders backs Walz in Harris veepstakes: He will 'speak up' for working people", "body": "Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) put his support behind Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz (D) as Vice President Harris's potential running mate, saying he will be the one to \"speak up\" for the working class.\n\n\"I had the opportunity to talk to your governor a few days ago and I am very impressed by him,\" Sanders said Saturday in an interview with Minnesota Public Radio. \"I think you have an excellent governor who understands the needs of working families.\"\n\n\"So, I hope very much that the Vice President elects a running mate who will speak up and take on powerful corporate interests,\" he continued. \"And I think Tim Walz is somebody who could do that.\"\n\nSanders is in Minnesota for \"Get-out-the-Vote\" efforts supporting Rep. Ilhan Omar (D). He hosted a town hall in Mankato, Minn., focused on working class voters.\n\nThe Vermont senator previously withheld his endorsement of Harris, arguing he wanted to see the vice president provide more specific commitment on issues important to the working class. Sanders, who ran against Harris and President Biden in 2020, said he wanted to help shape her campaign before offering his support.\n\nIn his interview Saturday, Sanders said he will do \"everything I can\" to help Harris beat former President Trump in November. That, he said, is also part of the reason he is visiting the North Star State.\n\n\"I think she has a strong record to run on along with President Biden and I think and believe that she is going to be speaking out not only on issues of climate change, not only on issues of women having the right to control their own bodies, not only protecting our democracy, but the needs of working families,\" he said.\n\nWalz is one of the shortlisted candidates to join Harris on the ballot this fall. First elected to Congress in 2006, Walz served in Congress for 12 years before heading back to Minnesota.\n\nHouse Democrats, and progressives in particular, are pulling for their colleague because his Midwestern roots and military background counter Harris well.\n\nRep. Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.) also signaled that Walz was an appealing choice because of his track record backing labor unions and working families. She said she wants someone who is pro-labor because winning working-class votes is important.\n\nWalz has been gaining national attention as Harris's rumored pick, especially since his blue-leaning state is a critical one that Democrats want to keep in the upcoming election.\n\nThe Minnesota Governor said it was \"an honor\" to be considered for the position. Tim Walz, according to multiple reports.\n\nThe 60-year-old is a known figure with major credibility in the party, particularly among House Democrats, given his long tenure in the lower chamber from 2007 to 2019. Democrats have also argued that Walz' past military service, teaching career, and Midwestern background would appeal to swing voters in must-win states, though his state isn't a vital battleground for Harris. The news was first reported by CNN.\n\nSome Democrats worried that Walz -- a progressive governor responsible for expanding labor rights, legalizing recreational marijuana, providing universal free lunches, and codifying the right to abortion in Minnesota -- isn't moderate enough to balance Harris' ticket. Republicans have taken to attacking her as an out-of-touch, \"radical\" liberal, and have leveled similar criticisms against Walz, including accusing him of allowing Minneapolis to burn for three nights amid rioting after police murdered George Floyd in 2020 by failing to coordinate an effective response quickly enough.\n\nBut Walz spent more than a decade in Congress representing a red, {"uri": "8261151470", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "05:14:42", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T05:14:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T05:14:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.the-sun.com/news/12120406/kamala-harris-vice-presidential-race-turns-bitter/", "title": "Dem divide 'intensifies' as battle for Kamala Harris' VP pick 'turns nasty'", "body": "THE battle to be Kamala Harris' running mate gets messy as the Democratic Party divides over their respective picks.\n\nPennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro and Minnesota Governor Tim Walz remain on Harris' shortlist for vice president and she is expected to make a final decision soon.\n\nHigh-ranking officials in the Democratic Party have all thrown support for their preferred picks while targeting others they deem unfit for the role.\n\nMany angered by the war in Gaza have looked at Shapiro, who is Jewish, over his stances on Israel and his handling of pro-Palestinian protests.\n\nPennsylvania Senator John Fetterman has raised concerns about Shapiro to Harris' team, reported Politico.\n\nSeveral members have pointed toward Walz to be Harris' pick meanwhile union leaders have publicly questioned whether or not Arizona Senator Mark Kelly should be picked.\n\n\"This is probably the closest thing to a primary that Democrats get this cycle and that explains why this has gotten so high stakes,\" a source who has worked on recent presidential campaigns told The Hill.\n\n\"Many Democrats are looking at this as the last opportunity to impact the ticket and potentially the last opportunity to have an impact on the White House until 2028 or 2032 so you are seeing a lot of campaigning.\"\n\nMany Democrats expected a chaotic situation after President Joe Biden dropped out of the race, however, his quick endorsement of Vice President Harris left no challengers emerging to take the party's nomination.\n\nHowever, the same can't be said for the race to be Harris' pick, which has become bitter.\n\n\"Veepstakes is normally a months-long process, and while the surprise of picking rising talent from the bench for the ticket has excited Democrats, it created a pressure-cooker environment over two weeks,\" a second strategist told the outlet.\n\n\"All opposition research and critique that would normally have time to breathe is being rushed out the door.\"\n\nA Harris ally told the outlet that the small time frame has contributed to the \"intensity of the moment.\"\n\n\"No one wants to make a mistake here,\" they said. \"The window is small and the stakes are high.\"\n\nHarris is expected to announce her pick on Tuesday at a scheduled public appearance with at Temple University in Philadelphia.\n\nIn a message to supporters late Monday evening, she said that she still has yet to make her decision.\n\n\"I know many of you are eager to find out who I will be selecting to join me on the campaign trail, and hopefully in the White House, as my Vice President,\" Harris wrote.\n\n\"Though I have not made my decision yet, it is important to me that grassroots supporters - like you - have direct updates about the state of the race,\" she said, giving voters a chance to sign up with a link to get the news of the announcement first.\n\nOver the weekend, Harris met with her vetting team, including former attorney general Eric Holder, who made in-depth presentations on each of Harris' finalists, reported Reuters.\n\nTuesday's rally will kick off a five-day tour of battleground states that will likely decide the election.\n\nHarris and her running mate will hit six major cities: Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; Eau Claire, Wisconsin; Detroit, Michigan; Durham, North Carolina; Phoenix, Arizona; and Las Vegas, Nevada.\n\nRallies will be held in each city, which will include college campuses, historically Black universities, union halls, and restaurants.\n\nIt comes as the stock market plummeted on Friday, coinciding with Harris earning enough delegate votes to secure the party's nomination.\n\nAfter Biden dropped out, her team worked to secure the packing from 1,976 party delegates to get the nomination in a formal roll call vote.\n\n\"Given that unique voice of a new generation, of a prosecutor and a woman when fundamental rights, especially reproductive rights, are on the line, it's almost as if the stars have aligned for her at this moment in history,\" California Senator Alex Padilla told the Associated Press.\n\nHowever, former President Donald Trump quickly hurled the blame at Harris over the economy on his social media platform Truth Social.\n\n\"Of course there is a massive market downturn. Kamala is even worse than Crooked Joe,\" Trump wrote after the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped more than 1,000 points in morning trading on Friday.\n\n\"Markets will NEVER accept the Radical Left Lunatic that DESTROYED San Francisco and California, as a whole. Next move, THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 2024! You can't play games with MARKETS. KAMALA CRASH!!!\" said Trump.\n\nThe stock market drop has been linked by economists to a less-than-stellar jobs growth report released on Friday morning.\n\nThe report showed that 114,000 news jobs were added to the US economy in July - below the expected 175,000 - signaling a potential recession.\n\nIn another post, Trump wrote: \"Voters have a choice - Trump prosperity, or the Kamala Crash & Great Depression of 2024, not to mention the probability of World Ward III if these very stupid people remain in office.", "source": {"uri": "the-sun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The US Sun"}, "authors": [{"uri": "cheyenne_r_ubiera@the-sun.com", "name": "Cheyenne R. {"uri": "2024-08-445627169", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "11:30:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T11:30:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T11:18:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/kamala-harris-trump-election-08-06-24/index.html", "title": "The latest on the 2024 presidential campaign", "body": "Key things to know about Harris' top possible candidates for running mate\n\nFrom CNN's Gregory Krieg, Piper Hudspeth Blackburn, Karl de Vries and Eric Bradner\n\nPennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro, Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz and Arizona Sen. Mark Kelly are reportedly among the top contenders to be Vice President Kamala Harris' running mate.\n\nShe's expected to make her decision ahead of a campaign rally in Philadelphia on Tuesday.\n\nHere are key things to know about each of the possible candidates:\n\nJosh Shapiro: Shapiro, who was previously the state's attorney general, was elected in a landslide victory in 2022, defeating a 2020 election-denying far-right state senator to become the third Jewish governor elected in the crucial swing state. During a stop in Philadelphia last month, Harris called Shapiro a \"great partner to the president and me.\" The assassination attempt against former President Donald Trump in Butler, Pennsylvania, placed the governor in the spotlight. His response to the death of Corey Comperatore, the Trump supporter who was killed while shielding his wife and daughter, has especially been lauded.\n\nTim Walz: Walz spent more than two decades in the Army National Guard, which included a deployment overseas after the 9/11 attacks, working as an educator and coach, before shockingly defeating a six-term Republican incumbent congressman in 2006, a wave year for Democrats. Walz remained when the tide rolled out, reelected to the typically red district repeatedly until he left to run for his current job in 2018. (The seat quickly returned to GOP control after his departure.) Walz's six years in charge of Minnesota have seen a remarkable series of political and social upheaval. First came the Covid-19 pandemic and then, in its midst, the murder of George Floyd by a White police officer, which set off global anti-racist demonstrations. Walz navigated it all - alongside more usual complaints over wasteful spending - well enough that, by the beginning of 2023, he was leading a Democratic trifecta in the state government.\n\nMark Kelly: Arizona Sen. Mark Kelly represents a state that Biden won by only 10,457 votes in 2020 and has national name recognition both as a former astronaut and the husband of former Rep. Gabby Giffords. He has been a reliable supporter of Democratic Party priorities while in office but has occasionally bucked his party, such as in 2023, when he flatly called the influx of undocumented migrants across the US southern border a \"crisis.\" If Kelly was elected to higher office, his seat would remain in Democratic hands as Gov.
