{"uri": "8261866174", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "13:16:01", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T13:16:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:14:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4313725531101227, "url": "https://www.dimsumdaily.hk/kamala-harris-taps-minnesota-governor-tim-walz-as-running-mate/", "title": "Kamala Harris taps Minnesota governor Tim Walz as running mate", "body": "6th August 2024 - (Washington) The announcement caps Walz's swift rise from a relative unknown to a leading voice in the Democratic Party's attacks on the Trump-aligned \"MAGA agenda.\" Walz, a former high school teacher and football coach, has evolved during his time as governor into a progressive populist figure, known for his pugilistic style and ability to connect with voters in the crucial Midwest region.\n\nWalz's selection underscores Harris' campaign focus on securing a path to victory that prioritises the \"blue wall\" states of the Midwest. Though Minnesota is slightly outside that sphere, Walz's background and appeal as a rural Democrat are seen as key assets in the fight against the Republican ticket of Donald Trump and Ohio Senator JD Vance.\n\n\"Tim Walz doesn't even register on the fear-o-meter,\" said Minnesota Republican strategist Kevin Poindexter, reflecting the surprise of many on the right at Walz's inclusion on the Harris ticket.\n\nIn the lead-up to his selection, Walz had emerged as a vocal defender of President Joe Biden and a reliable, energetic advocate for Harris. His ability to deliver \"memorable haymakers\" against Republicans, as well as his personal story of overcoming infertility struggles, have endeared him to many in the Democratic base.\n\nAs governor, Walz has navigated a divided government, but the Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party's recent trifecta victory in Minnesota has allowed him to sign into law a raft of expansive social welfare programs and {"uri": "8261875625", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "13:21:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T13:21:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:20:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4196078479290009, "url": "https://omaha.com/news/state-regional/government-politics/elections/native-nebraskan-tim-walz-now-minnesota-governor-named-kamala-harris-vice-presidential-pick/article_8303908e-5389-11ef-b753-cf684e16966b.html", "title": "Native Nebraskan Tim Walz, now Minnesota governor, named Kamala Harris' vice presidential pick", "body": "While Tim Walz established himself as a national political figure in Minnesota, the Democratic vice presidential candidate's life story is deeply rooted in Nebraska.\n\nDemocratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris' allies told media outlets Tuesday she would name the Minnesota governor as her vice presidential selection.\n\nThe 60-year-old was born in West Point.\n\nHe graduated from Butte High School.\n\nHe served in the Nebraska Army National Guard for over a decade.\n\nHe graduated from Chadron State College.\n\nHe and his wife also taught school in Alliance before they moved to her native state of Minnesota in 1996.\n\n\"We got a great base for future success,\" Walz once said of his days at Chadron State. \"I believe the record shows that we have been able to go on and compete very well.\"\n\nNow as Kamala Harris' choice as vice president and running mate, he will compete this fall for a chance to join her in the White House.\n\nWalz was born on April 6, 1964 in West Point, the son of Jim and Darlene Walz. He spent most of his childhood in Valentine before his family moved to Butte during his sophomore year of high school.\n\nHe graduated from Butte High School in 1982. But even before completing high school, just two days after turning 17, he got his family's permission to enlist in the Nebraska Army National Guard.\n\nGuard records show he completed his basic training in the summer before his senior year at Butte.\n\nWalz enrolled at Chadron State in 1982 and used the GI bill to complete his degree in education in 1989. For a time in 1985, he also took classes in East Asia Studies at the University of Houston.\n\nAfter graduating from Chadron, the sergeant briefly served full time in the guard at the armory in Alliance.\n\nBut in 1990, he left that job to spend a year teaching in China as part of Harvard University's WorldTeach program. He taught American history, culture and English to Chinese high school students.\n\nHe called it a once in a lifetime experience, finding the people in the Communist country kind and generous. Though his students did not celebrate Christmas, they cut down a pine tree, decorated it and brought it to his room on Christmas Eve.\n\n\"Going there was one of the best things I've ever done,\" he later told the Nebraska guard's newspaper after he returned to his home state and resumed his guard service.\n\nFollowing the year teaching in China, Walz became a teacher in Alliance, teaching social studies and geography to middle school and high school students. He was known for leading groups of students on summer trips abroad to China.\n\nDuring his years in Alliance, he also met his wife, Gwen, a native of Minnesota. The two got married during a trip to China and spent their honeymoon leading two high school tour groups.\n\nThen in 1996, the couple moved to Mankato, Minnesota, Gwen's hometown. There, he continued to teach and serve in the guard, ultimately retiring after 24 years of total guard service.\n\nMinnesota was also where Walz launched his political career. In 2006, the Democrat ran for an won a seat in Congress, upsetting a six-term incumbent Republican. After six terms in Washington, he was elected Minnesota governor in 2018 and re-elected in 2022.\n\nIn 2014, the then-congressman returned to Chadron State to give the commencement address and to receive a distinguished alumni award.\n\nWalz said he appreciated that his alma mater provided middle class families like his the opportunity to earn a college education.\n\n\"The professors at this college wanted us to succeed,\" Walz said during his visit. \"The door was always open for us to learn and to grow.\"\n\nOur best Omaha staff photos & videos of August 2024", "source": {"uri": "omaha.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Omaha.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "henry_j_cordes@omaha.com", "name": "Henry J. But starting Tuesday in Philadelphia, she will kick off a seven-state tour with her as-yet-unannounced vice presidential nominee in tow.\n\nThe Philadelphia stop is scheduled to take place at the Liacouras Center at Temple University, and marks Harris' first appearance in Philadelphia since beginning her presidential campaign. Harris' rally is also the Liacouras Center's second time this summer hosting a presidential rally, with Trump having stopped there back in June.\n\nHarris' Philly visit is scheduled to be her first with her running mate, whoever it may be. Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro is among the front-runners for the nomination, but has so far remained mum about his interest in the job when asked about it by reporters.\n\nFollowing her stop in Philly, Harris is scheduled to embark in a multi-state tour, with appearances throughout the week in Wisconsin, Michigan, North Carolina, Georgia, Arizona, and Nevada, the White House said.\n\nTrump and his running mate, U.S. Sen. JD Vance of Ohio, have one campaign rally scheduled Saturday in Atlanta, where Harris held a rally earlier this week. That event is scheduled to begin at 5 p.m.\n\nThe pair has one other rally scheduled, according to the Trump campaign's website as of Friday afternoon. or not, as the case may be.\n\nPrompted by a spate of TikToks from fan account for Disney Channel actor Jason Earles named 'jasonearlesisfreakinghawt', a series of photoshopped images claiming that Harris has selected the star as her running mate have gone viral.\n\n\"Kamala Harris will announce Disney Star Jason Earles asVP in next six, seven days,\" reads a headline doctored to appear as though it had been reported by British newspaper The Guardian.\n\n\"BREAKING NEWS: Kamala Harris has announced Jason Earles, former Disney Star, as presidential running mate,\" reads another fake screenshot from the same TikTok, with over 3.2 million views.\n\nThe account has posted five further TikToks at the time of reporting, with a combined 5.7 million views on the fake news.\n\nThe further posts feature Earles, who is best known for playing Miley Cyrus's on-screen older brother Jackson in Disney Channel sitcom Hannah Montana, in fake images and news articles indicating that he has turned his career to politics - and been successful enough to be selected as Harris's running mate.\n\nThe account also claims that Earles \"achieved a law degree from the University of Chicago in 2016 and has been involved in politics since.\" He has not done either of these things.\n\nTL;DR - no, Jason Earles has not been selected as Kamala Harris's running mate.\n\nIn the land of truth, vice president Kamala Harris is expected to announce her actual running partner shortly, with Forbes reporting that Pennsyvlania Gov. Shapiro and Minnesota Gov. Walz are the frontrunners for the No. 2 spot.\n\nAccording to the same article, Buttigieg, Arizona Sen. Kelly, Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear and Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker have also been interviewed by Harris's team.\n\nJason Earles, meanwhile, last appeared in a public facing role during meta-Disney Channel spinoff High School Musical: The Musical: The Series, in 2023.\n\nShare your thoughts! Tim Walz.\n\nAround 6:30 p.m. Eastern Time Monday, Dan Green posted on the social media site X that he was near Walz's home and that a \"bunch of black SUV's just rolled out.\"\n\n\"I am not a betting man but the vibe seemed very 'this guy just got picked as VP,' he wrote. \"Feel free to interpret how you wish!\"\n\nGreen later added he has \"no idea what's going on\" and admitted he was only parked there for five to 10 minutes.\n\nThe tweet was enough to spark social media users, particularly after a similar scene was captured with Ohio Sen. J.D. Vance, who was seen departing his Cincinnati home in a motorcade before being named former President Donald Trump's running mate. Tim Walz, chosen on Tuesday to be Vice President Kamala Harris' running mate, was a longtime educator - just like his wife.\n\nGwen Walz has taught in public, alternative and migrant schools, as well as prisons. She also served as an administrator and coordinator at Mankato Area Public Schools, a school district in the congressional district her husband represented from 2007 to 2019.\n\nHer first public event as Minnesota first lady was a rally in support of voting rights restoration for felons. She has also toured state prisons and helped recruit an assistant commissioner working to install a new college curriculum behind prison walls, among other things, according to a report from Minnesota Public Radio.\n\n\"Gwen understands that corrections must be an inclusive component of our education system, and by expanding opportunity, our state can dramatically reduce recidivism rates and most importantly, transform lives,\" reads her official biography page.\n\nWalz first met her husband in western Nebraska, where she began her career teaching English, according to her official biography. They were married in 1994, Shortly after, the two established Educational Travel Adventures, Inc., which organized annual educational trips to China for students.\n\nThe couple have two children: Hope, a recent graduate of Montana State University, and Gus, who is in high school.\n\nSpeaking about her husband shortly after he took office in 2019, Walz told Twin Cities PBS: \"I make no mistake about it, Tim is going to make the decisions. And he did when he was in Congress. And I think we worked toward usually the same end, but we really trust one another.\"\n\nWalz was born in Glencoe, Minnesota, and grew up in the western part of the state. Both her parents were teachers and small-business owners. Walz was educated at Gustavus Adolphus College and Minnesota State University.\n\nCNN's Kaanita Iyer contributed to this report.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros.
